title: Susan B. Anthony Papers: Daybook and Diaries, 1856-1906; Diaries; 1877

entries.fullText:
Whoever finds this
will be liberally rewarded
by returning it to the owner
Susan B. Anthony
no. 7 Madison Street
Dochester(sic)
N. Y.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is offering a reward for the return of a lost item at her address in Dochester, NY.

entries.fullText: At Ms. Stantons - all her children, except Daniel Cady in Florida & Gerrit Smith - Lorna & her husband at home to new years dinner. But my dear mother has only her one child Mary her eldest home - Guelma, three years gone to the beyond, her third born Hannah in Leavenworth. Has been [?] of lung difficulty for nearly a year. her 4th Daniel is at his home Leavenworth & her 6th & youngest born J. Merritt at his home Fort Scott Kan- Mary the 5th with Mother & Susan the 2nd home at [?]. it is the first time in years so few of us have been at home. a terrible snow storm in P.M. & Night
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends New Year's Day at Ms. Stanton's with family and friends. She notes that her mother is unwell and that many of her siblings are living in different cities.

entries.fullText:
At Mrs. Stanton's-
working on address to
Congress -but did
not get one that we
thought worthy to present
entries.summaryText: Working on address to Congress at Mrs. Stanton's, but did not find one worthy to present.

entries.fullText: Went to B's one of these days to Mr. Appleton's and got their final answer about publishing history of U.S. movement --- "too hard times for them to undertake so expensive a job --- dreadfully disappointed but still hope they may do it when the times get better.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Mr. Appleton's to get their final answer about publishing history of U.S. movement. They declined due to the expensive cost, but Susan still hopes they may do it when the times get better.

entries.fullText:
9th Washington National W. R
Convention- Lincoln Hall-
Mrs. Stanton President- She & self
stopped at Senator Sargents -
Mrs Gage, Mrs Blake, Miss Couzins
present - Belva A Lockwood
made an excellent speech on
the Supreme Court -
streets very sloppy - but
audiences good - Dr Mary
Walker on hand first one & on
the platform before we arrived
- AH Diddle spoke this evg -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the 9th Washington National W. R Convention at Lincoln Hall in Washington, D.C. and hears speeches from Mrs. Stanton, Belva A Lockwood, and AH Diddle. Dr Mary Walker is also present.

entries.fullText:
[Eighth] Ninth Washington National
W. R. Convention,
Boring to day - still the
audiences splendid -
nothing seems ordinarily
pleasant to me - the
speaking not equal - but
it is doubtless myself
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the 9th Washington National W. R Convention in Washington, D.C. and finds the day boring despite the good audiences.

entries.fullText:
Washington - worked
on the Petitions at
Mrs Spencers until 3.
P. M. then went with
her to the House - to get
them in the hands of M. C.
there are 23 States represented -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked on petitions in Washington and went with Mrs. Spencer to the House to get them in the hands of M.C. There are 23 states represented.

entries.fullText:
Petitions from 23 states
presented in the H. R. this
A.M. - by 27 different
members - - also a
unanimous report of
the Judiciary Committee
on Mrs. Lockwoods petition
for removal of legal
disability of women to
practice law
Mrs Stanton left
for home this A.M.-
entries.summaryText: Petitions from 23 states were presented in the House of Representatives by 27 different members. There was also a unanimous report of the Judiciary Committee on Mrs. Lockwood's petition for removal of legal disability of women to practice law. Mrs. Stanton left for home.

entries.fullText:
Petitions presented
in the Senate - Mr Sargent
leading off & making a nice
little speech - followed
by other Senators - Dawes
of Mass. made approving remarks
Cameron of Penn.
made disagreeable comments
showing he was an opponent.
entries.summaryText: Petitions presented in the Senate by Mr Sargent, followed by other Senators, including Dawes and Cameron, who made disagreeable comments.

entries.fullText:
Went to Mrs Spencer
again & worked on
petitions all day -
at eve called on
Mrs Lockwood & then
Mrs Gage, Mrs Ricker
& Mrs [Le Good Dye?]
Mrs Gage did not
return my kiss - but
turned her cheek -
- Thence to [??] Robert
Purvis- found him
very ill - but better -
- seemed very glad to
see me - Found
Miss [Couzzin's?] at Mr
Sargent's - she staid all night
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked on petitions all day at Mrs Spencer's, then visited Mrs Lockwood, Mrs Gage, Mrs Ricker, and Mrs [Le Good Dye?]. She also visited Robert Purvis, who was ill but seemed glad to see her. She found Miss [Couzzin's?] at Mr Sargent's, where she stayed all night.

entries.fullText:
Left Washington on the
7:40 - Northern Central
route - this evening -
went to Ms Spencers at
10 & worked on Convention
report until 5 P.M. then
back to Mr Sargents to
dinner & off for home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Washington and worked on a convention report before heading home.

entries.fullText:
Arrived home -
Rochester - at 5 P.M.
found mother feeble
but bright & very
comfortable - Sister
May looking better
than last October -
- The letters from
sister Hannah are
very discouraging -
her cough & hard
breathing increase steady
- has severe spasms so that
breath & power to speak stop -
-It seems too cruel that she
must suffer thus & go down
& down.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived home in Rochester and found her mother and sister well, but her sister Hannah's health was deteriorating.

entries.fullText:
Left home on 10:45 P.M.
train for [Cadiz], [????]
Cleveland & Ulrichsville
-- niece Maggie
came to no. 7. at
2 P.M. & spent afternoon
--I had to leave & go
down to Dr. Allen's _
he has made another
failure on this
plate _ _ Maggie
says her Pa has never
intimated to her that
he was specially interested in
Miss M nor does she speak her
name before him _ It is now
fully two years since he settled
his special attention upon her
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travels to Cadiz, Cleveland, and Ulrichsville, and mentions her niece Maggie and Dr. Allen's recent failure. She also discusses Maggie's father's lack of interest in Miss M.

entries.fullText:
[???????] Cleveland
at 7 & had 10 &
Ulricksville at noon --
waited till 4 -- then
to Cadiz Station &
waited [?] hours -- &
then reached Cadiz
at 8.10 -- found
tolerable hotel
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travels to Cleveland, Ulricksville, and Cadiz, and mentions finding a tolerable hotel upon arrival in Cadiz.

entries.fullText:
At Cadiz - spent
the day in my room
writing letters and
lounging - without
my trunk- I feel
a little lost-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day in her room at Cadiz, feeling a little lost without her trunk.

entries.fullText:
Cadiz, Ohio - W. B. Hearn
Central Hotel -
John M. Holmes-
Counottou Harrison Co. O.
drove 14 miles _ Mr. & Mrs.Thomas
Green of Freeport - Har. Co. drove
18 miles , to lecture
Mrs Maria B. Becker _ [?????] leader
Mattie E. Phillips ] bright young
Lizzie T. McFadden ] girls-
Aunt came this
A.M. all right -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled to Cadiz, Ohio and met with various people, including Mrs. Maria B. Becker and three bright young girls. Her aunt also arrived safely.

entries.fullText:
Zanesville - O. Dr L. M. Gray
St. Lawrence Hotel -
Miss Lizzie Martin lives
9 miles out - strange specimens - tells
of her loves & delights in being kissed
with arms around her and hand squeezed -
I told her she talked like a
fool. Said he was 32 and she
must be cracked - poor
thing with nothing to do -
Mr. T. J. Magginus
subscribed for ballot box -
had a fair audience.
Got letter from Mr. Slayton with list
of engagements to
consider 1st
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day in Zanesville, Ohio, where she met with Dr L. M. Gray, Miss Lizzie Martin, and Mr. T. J. Magginus, and received a letter from Mr. Slayton.

entries.fullText:
- Dr Gray frightened
of his 2nd nights engagement
with me - he had
lost hearing by a
Mr Muer Saturday night - so he
telegraphed me that
he must cancel
to night - rather rude?
Spent day at
Laurence Hotel Mr
& Mrs Maginnis called -
wrote letters to Sister
Hannah & Mary - brother
Dan. Mrs. Stanton, Mrs
Williams & Mrs Sherman
Justin Badley is Nov 5th
judge of the Presidential
Commission-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day at the Laurence Hotel, where she received a visit from Mr. & Mrs Maginnis and wrote letters to her family. She also mentions Dr Gray cancelling their engagement due to hearing loss and Justin Badley being appointed judge of the Presidential Commission on November 5th.

entries.fullText:
Wilmington, Ohio - $25
Frank Browning
Mr. B. & Mr. Hilderbrand
met me at Depot - Mr. H. took
me to Hotel - too poor &
too noisy - fine audience
in a Baptist church - got
3 subscribers for the Ballot Box
David L. Hadley and [Rhodes?]
C. Worthington Quakers - &
Carrie Browning -
Letter here from Mr Marshall
saying I was to be
the guest of Mrs. Monroe
an earnest friend of Mr. S.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Wilmington, Ohio, meets with Frank Browning, Mr. B., and Mr. Hilderbrand, and gets three subscribers for the Ballot Box. She also receives a letter from Mr. Marshall saying she will be the guest of Mrs. Monroe.

entries.fullText:
Xenia, O. - $25
Stine & Marshall
Was guest of Mr. & Mrs.
J. B. Monroe - old abolitionists -
- just elegant place - the
first time I have slept & eaten
in a private house or had a
"Christian cup of coffee" - My
cold getting worse - head
& eyes feeling it - Mrs. Matt
Allison - Fannie Ekin - sister
of dear Mrs. Starrett of [?]
called on me - had a fine
audience - but it is cruel
to go to bed at 12 to be called
at 5 - but so it is to be
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Xenia, Ohio, and stays with Mr. and Mrs. J. B. Monroe, old abolitionists. She meets with Mrs. Matt Allison and Fannie Ekin, and has a fine audience. However, she is suffering from a cold and is being woken up early.

entries.fullText: Left Xenia at 6.20 - found on train Mr. A. L. Peat formerly of Victor, Ontario Co. - N.Y. - the friend & helper of all Sister Mary & M. R. lecturers then - now lives at Lafayette Ind. with his daughter Emma Gilbert - niece Ann Elias most intimate friend & artist is married to Peter B. Loomis and lives at Jackson, Mich. - arrived late at P.M. dingy dirty little hotel - decent audience but their 2/3 [amounted?] to $17.60 Mrs. Dr. Cotton- Mrs. P.J. Hammond & Mrs. Dr. Anderson - the best women Mrs. A.L. Handarsona - of Lebanon - Boone Co. came to hear me - my cold is getting fearfully severe
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Zionsville, Indiana, and describes the people she meets and the state of her cold.

entries.fullText: Got up at 2 A.M. & took train at 2.45 to this City- could not think of being shut up in that dingy little hole over Sunday- Mrs. Livermore addressed the Legislature here yesterday P.M.- gave her superfluous known last evening & spoke in Unitarian Church this A.M. - I laid on bed until 11 O clock - my cold settling down upon my lungs
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Danville, Illinois, and describes her decision to leave her hotel and her activities for the day.

entries.fullText:
Left Ind. at 8 A.M. and
reached D. 11.40. took dinner
and went to bed again, though
before doing so Mrs. Rick, the
proprietor's wife, went with
me to a homeopathic doctor
Alexander Pollock, and he gave
Mercurius something powder.
Had a telegram from
brother P.A. saying Lecture
through March, April and May -
that Sister Hannah was about
the same - it is hard not to up and
see her, but I shall doubtless be able
to her more good by having no way.
couldn't go to sleep - old
rat smell - So took train
at 3 A.M. for Champaign
& when there couldn't ge a
bed & had to sit up the rest of night.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Danville, Illinois, visits a homeopathic doctor, receives a telegram from her brother, and takes a train to Champaign.

entries.fullText:
Let Champaign at 7:30
on Freight Train- met cordial
welcome from Mrs. Bullock & her
friend Mrs. J. L. Henning of
Plano, Ill. who was visiting her
went strait to bed & slept pretty
good until 2 P.M. She had friends to Mrs. & Mr. Lucy E. Penfield
& Mrs. Laura E. Gifford. Had
fine audience & put
in a good nights sleep
after my lecture- though
my cough annoyed me a good deal.
- Found a letter here from dear
invalid Sister Hannah trying to
make the best account of herself-
it relieves me ever so much though
from the feeling that I must go to her
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Rantoul, Illinois, gives a lecture, and receives a letter from her sister.

entries.fullText:
Loda Ill $25
D. M. Morgan
Went P.M. at the
Morgans - & night at
Mr. Pelton's - daughter
Jennie - nice girl.
Mrs Uriah Copp - a very
handsome young wife
of an old man
Lawyer - hyde bound
Presbyterian - fine
musician & wants to
teach - do something -
but husband won't let her.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent time in Loda Ill with D. M. Morgan, Mr. Pelton, Jennie, and Mrs Uriah Copp. She also met a lawyer who is a Presbyterian and a fine musician but whose husband won't let her teach.

entries.fullText:
Streator - Ill $50-
Sam'l G. Smyth
Stopped at Wm. F. Parker's -
formerly of Cleveland - good time
but cough broke out while I was
speaking - daughter named
Abby - after Abby Kelly -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited Streator - Ill and stayed at Wm. F. Parker's, formerly of Cleveland. She had a good time but her cough broke out while she was speaking. She also met Abby Kelly's namesake daughter.

entries.fullText:
First letter from Sister
Mary - Rec'd here - all
well there - stopped at
little tucked up hotel -
good audience -
my share $45. - better
than Not[?] -
The Prof. of the
College introduced
me here -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Sister Mary and performs a lecture at a college in Eureka, Louisiana.

entries.fullText:
Thos. Handacker
Rev. G Wiley Martin -
M. E. called at Sherman
Hotel - & invited me to give
Temperance lecture in his
Church Sunday night - I
consented - though ought
not to with such a cold
- got letter from brother D.R.
Had fine audience
Methodist Minister
- & I was sorry
enough. I had drawn
a line on amusements
- for to offend a
minister is to have
him arrayed against
our cause - Mr &
Mrs Crane told me
not to mind what
he said - That he
would repent it - And
they agreed with me
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is invited to give a Temperance lecture at a church in Washington, Louisiana and receives advice from Mr. and Mrs. Crane after offending a Methodist Minister.

entries.fullText:
At Washington - Staid
in bed all forenoon -
had gruel brot up to me
--- spoke in evening in
M.E. Church - told the
story of my father & the Dancing
School at Centre Falls - the best
art of his life - & then of the
Puget Sound M. E. Minister
who told his deacons he would
reprimand & expel from church
young women & young men for
dancing - When complaint was
made by a half dozzen of Deacons
& elders who neither chewed or smoke
- & Mr Martin said while personally
he agreed with me & he considered
I made direct insult to him as a
entries.summaryText: Spoke at M.E. Church in Washington and told stories about my father and the Puget Sound M. E. Minister who wanted to expel young people for dancing.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Crane sent word to
me not to mind the Minister
that he would be sorry that he told
me I had insulted him -
Mr Campbell backed out & Mr
A. H. Price - understood my lecture
at Knoxville - Judge R. L. Hammond
was first to speak to me - Said he was
interested - [?] said instructed -
Mrs John Wilder - promised to organize
six women came over from Maquon.
Mrs. C W Barker, A. H. Barker,
A. P. Miller, A. M. Donason,
Bell Patton, L. J. Shier, & R. M.
Lothard - & returned home at 11:30
entries.summaryText: Received a message from Mrs Crane, Mr Campbell backed out, and spoke to several people in Knoxville about my lecture.

entries.fullText:
Elmwood, Ill. $25-
E.R. Brown.
Stopped at with the Browns
- good time - Splendid
audience - Wilford Clark
Andrew - son of Dr Andrew
& cousin Emeline Read - [Uncle?]
Aaron Read's daughter - lives
here - nice little woman for
wife - Very delicate with lungs
Emma Jane Andrew - married
Elbert H. Preston & lives
at New Britain Ct -
Good letter from Mrs. Stanton
& one from Bob & Hattie the
latter shows deep thought. Mrs.
Hiram Brown, earnest - Lois
& Lester - the children of E.R. Lester
[?] very like the Hutchinsons
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Elmwood, Ill. where she stayed with the Browns and had a good time. She also mentions various people she met and received letters from.

entries.fullText:
Canton Ill $25-
Johnson & Henkle
Fine audience here -
The young men must
have netted $100. Said they
had lost on every woman
lecturer - but they paid
each of them $50, $75, or 100 -
- Mr Johnson & Mr
Henkle called at
Hotel - good new house -
Got [?] subscribers
here -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Canton, Ill where she spoke to a fine audience and met with Johnson and Henkle who had lost money on every woman lecturer they had paid but still paid her $25.

entries.fullText:
Mrs George Little
Miss Fanny Bagley & friend
met me at depot - at 5 PM
after a tedious dragging
on coal & freight trains from
11:20 AM. Took me to
her mother's house. Mrs J.
C. Bagley - Mr B a lawyer
& member of Congress -
spoke in M.E. Church -
Mr Wolfe - Pastor.
Carried my audience
Mine was the first W. S.
lecture ever given at R.
& everyone was surprised
at the large note.
Letter here from Mrs. Sargent
of work & brother Eugene &
Frank Mosher - about sister H,
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gives a lecture in Rushville, Illinois, which was the first W.S. lecture ever given there. She also receives a letter from Mrs. Sargent about work and her brother Eugene and Frank Mosher regarding sister H.

entries.fullText:
George L. Purell
Was called at 6 AM. Took
splendid breakfast. [?]
& peaches & lots of elegant
cream - & reached
Vermont at 9 A.M. &
again a dingy hotel
but it is a rest from visiting
H. L. Thomas - the P.M.
called - also Mrs Edward
(Anna) Hamer - both
Quakers - a large Q. element
here. Splendid audience
- the hotel people very kind.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gives a lecture in Vermont, Illinois and meets with H.L. Thomas and Mrs. Edward (Anna) Hamer, both Quakers. She also enjoys a splendid breakfast and a rest at a dingy hotel.

entries.fullText:
White Hall -- Ill. -- $25
Ira D. Vedder
Reached W. H. at 5 P. M --
Went to Mr Higbee's
had short rest & slept &
a cup of coffee & to the
platform at 8 -- a good
audience -- good vote --
7 subscribers for the B. B.
Miss M. Keller Righter
of Greenview is a lecturer
on Phrenology studies
& graduated with the
[Fowlers?] & Wells -- at New York
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reached White Hall, Illinois, gave a speech and got 7 subscribers for the B.B. She also met Miss M. Keller Righter who is a lecturer on Phrenology studies and graduated with the [Fowlers?] & Wells in New York.

entries.fullText:
At Whitehall --
Spoke on Temperance
in the Methodist Church
-- Large audience
& tolerably fair speech
-- got letter after
a nice election, saying
temperance ticket
carried -- & due
share of glory
given to Miss A's
speech Friday night.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a speech on Temperance in the Methodist Church in Whitehall, Illinois. She received a letter saying the temperance ticket carried and that she was given a share of the glory for her speech on Friday night.

entries.fullText:
Jerseyville, Ill. $25
W. W. Edar
Had fine audience
lecture delightful.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture in Jerseyville, Illinois to a fine audience.

entries.fullText:
Nashville, Ill. $25
Wassell Bros -- Wassell
Had 2 hours in
St - Louis - lunched with
Mrs. Virginia L. Minor -- &
called on nephew Arthur
Mosher's wife Mattie Brown
& Arthur went with us
across River to Depot -
reached Nashville at 6.30
had fine audience - a
Leery lawyer introduced
me & followed me with
a splendid statement of the case ?
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled from St. Louis to Nashville, Illinois, where she gave a lecture to a fine audience. She also met with various people, including Mrs. Virginia L. Minor and Arthur Mosher's wife Mattie Brown.

entries.fullText:
Ashley - Ill- $25
C.E. Hammond
A lady Post Master
here for last 7 years
Miss Cynthia B. Lacy
-had fair audience
entries.summaryText: Meeting in Ashley with C.E. Hammond, a lady Post Master, and Miss Cynthia B. Lacy.

entries.fullText:
Mt. Vernon. Ill - $25
C. J. Hays
A blue letter, here, from
Sister Mary - it is a
Shame that she must
suffer so much from
such selfishness as
she has around her
entries.summaryText: Meeting in Mt. Vernon with C. J. Hays and a discussion about a letter from Sister Mary and her suffering from selfishness around her.

entries.fullText:
- Letter from sister Mary
written Monday eve - with
letters from Eugene & Hannah
very discouraging - but I have
letter of a much later date - more
hopeful -- Poor sister
Mary has a hard row with
all her trials at no 7.
Had fine audience
& made a good speech
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from sister Mary and had a good speech.

entries.fullText:
Found letters from brother D.R.
with St. Jo & Hannibal & T. W. & W.
R.R. passes - & various other
letters - but no no fresh word from
sister Hannah - Slayton
says I must not go to
Leavenworth until May -
how can I wait two
months longer before seeing
dear H. -
Had small audience
& wiggled between reading
my 16th amendment speech
& extemporizing - & made
a very unsatisfactory effort
entries.summaryText: Received letters from brother D.R. and had a small audience.

entries.fullText:
At Carbondale - Ill
with Uncle David Anthony's
son William P. by first wife
Aunt Phebe Turner - of
South Adams Mass -
daughter Frank E. & her
partner Elizabeth Ann
Haskell - they are in the
millinery & ladies furnishing
business - cool & dank &
dark day -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with family and friends in Carbondale, Illinois.

entries.fullText:
Anna - Ill 2/3
A. J. Alden $24
Took train from
Carbondale at 11.15 -
- splendid audience
at Anna - & splendid
women called on
me - Mrs. W. Kirkpatrick
& Mrs M. A. Dodds & others
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Anna, Illinois and meets with local women.

geographicalLocations: Junction of the Ohio with the Father of Waters
entries.fullText:
Cairo - Ill. $20
A. A. Milburn
Got letter from sister Mary
- Stopped St. Charles -
Mrs Jacob Martin ill -
but sent for me to tea - I
was in bed & couldn't see
Mr M. who came for me
Had splendid audience -
- The location of Cairo
at Junction of the Ohio
with the Father of Waters
is very lovely -
Left C on the 11.20 train
after lecture & went to Carbondale
got there at 1.30 - found cousin
[?] gone home her mother
very ill
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a splendid audience in Cairo, Illinois, despite Mrs. Jacob Martin being ill and Susan being in bed. She then left for Carbondale.

entries.fullText:
Marion -Ill 2/3
J. C. Mitchell
Slept till 10 A.M -
left Carbondale at - 2
P.M. - good audience
at Marion - Mr
Copeland - the ed - Repub
paper took up the lecture -
Mitchell the P.M. dropped it -
- two big lumber waggon loads
of people came from two different
directions 12 miles each -
Mrs. Mitchel - a teacher from
Corinth Ill - in one - & Mrs
Rickart - Cartersville - Ill - the
other --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a good audience in Marion, Illinois and two big lumber waggon loads of people came from two different directions.

entries.fullText:
Rev. E. L. James-
Got letter from sister H
here - she is surely losing
ground daily
M Earl - Mrs H. M,
Mary Cutler's son in law
met me at Depot - saving
land - they live two miles west
from Depot. Had most cordial
visits with Mrs Cutler. &
nice good dinner and tea -
and magnificent coffee - [?]
audience - it literally poured -
Mrs. C. went with me to Mr
Ducks after lecture at 1 [?]
Mr. B went to Depot with me - a train
till 3.30 - then heard train [?]
at 4.20 - he left - I got to [?] at 6.17
A.M. [?] I tried to do
[?] train time for [?] 12 noon.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Cobden, IL, where she met with Rev. E. L. James, M Earl, Mrs H. M, and Mary Cutler's son-in-law. She had a good dinner and tea with Mrs. Cutler and gave a lecture to a large audience. She also visited Mr. Ducks and took a train at 4.20 pm.

entries.fullText:
R. L. Anderson
Letter here from Brother P. R.
saying he had watched sister
Hannah very close - & was
satisfied she was losing slowly -
feared the worst but not in
months, perhaps years he wrote
this, fearing he had written too
strongly to me a month ago
the letter 21st Feb- got [?]
form Sister H. [?]
same date- Sunday- she
had taken magretin treatment
a week from Dr. Pier- & feels
a good deal stronger- had took
to Buy tea & milk punch
cream 3 & 4 times a day-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a letter she received from Brother P. R. regarding the health of sister Hannah. She also mentions that sister Hannah had taken magretin treatment from Dr. Pier and feels stronger.

entries.fullText:
Fairfield Ill $25
Frank K. Israel
Left McLeansburg at 2.50
A.M. - Enfield at 4.20,
stopped there till 8 A:M
Had good audience
- it rained at eve -
& when lecture was
out it snowed - so
walked home - hotel -
Dales! in six inches of snow
got letter here from
sister May -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony lectures in Fairfield, Illinois, despite the rain and snow.

entries.fullText:
At Fairfield
Spoke in M.E.
Church - the minister
wouldn’t allow a
collection taken - the
people dreadfully
vexed about it -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at a church in Fairfield, but the minister refuses to allow a collection to be taken, causing frustration among the people.

entries.fullText:
Left Fairfield at 9 A.M
& went round via Vincennes
- reached C. at 5 P. M --
- tired out -- Stafford
Hotel -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled from Fairfield to Carmi, Illinois via Vincennes and stayed at Stafford Hotel.

entries.fullText:
Received letter from Sister
Hannah this AM, mailed the [?]
at Leavenworth - sharing that she is
failing very rapidly - she says
keep on lecturing - but it
seems cruel not to go to her
at once - Sister Annie & brother
D.R. do everything they can - then
her husband & son Frank - but
none of them stay with her -
Wrote sister Mary to let Louise
fix off for L. at once -
Rode 10 miles from
Grayville in a buggy -
Stopped at Lucius Harris -
- good audience --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from her sister Hannah who is failing rapidly. She wrote to her sister Mary to let Louise fix off for L. at once. She rode 10 miles from Grayville in a buggy and stopped at Lucius Harris where she had a good audience.

entries.fullText: The mayor R. S. Gordon met me at depot - Mr Hamill getting out his paper-The Register-stopped Grand Central Hotel- better than the average. Sent home to sister Mary for [?]-$100- This is Mt Zion of "The Jericho Road" novel-a John (Jack) Hahberton, the author used to live here - his uncle the squire who brot up Jack still lives-
entries.summaryText: Met with the mayor and stayed at the Grand Central Hotel in Mt Carmel, IIl. Mentioned the novel "The Jericho Road" and its author John (Jack) Hahberton.

entries.fullText: Dined at Mr Hughes sister Annie Hughes a regular Southern democrat - every one told me to wait till the 4.40 train to go to Princeton - rained & no ferryboat at landing got into a skiff & was rowed half over the Wabash when the driver shouted the train is gone-so all was lost & I set back - took 6.10 freight train for Vincennes else went [?] Boonville too
entries.summaryText: Had dinner with Mr Hughes and his sister Annie Hughes, a Southern democrat. Missed the train due to rain and no ferryboat, had to take a freight train to Vincennes.

entries.fullText: Had hard straw mattress at Vincennes hotel. Took train at 9:40 - Stopped two hours & dined at St. Georges Hotel at Evansville & reached Boonville at 4pm. Mrs. Piatt and Beillinger met me at train & escorted me to Eagle Hotel - oh dear - that any housekeeper could set a woman down in such a place. Had splendid audience got six subscribers to the Ballot Box - But found no letters or papers here
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Vincennes to Boonville, meets with Robert M. Piatt, and has a successful speech.

entries.fullText: Left Boonville Ind. at 9 A.M. Poor Mrs. G. Husk--the landlady of The Eagle Hotel--a poor apology for a hotel--does everything & then Mr. G. Husk is a [?] drove to squirt tobacco juice over her red-hot stoves-- Mr & Mrs Piatt called & accompanied me to the Depot-- beautiful day but cold-- reached Vincennes at noon bound to stop here at the Union Depot Hotel until Monday A.M. 4 oclock-- Walked into the city at 9 P.M. & got $50. P.O. order & sent to sister Hannah
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Boonville and travels to Vincennes, where she stays at the Union Depot Hotel and sends money to her sister.

entries.fullText: - at 9 A.M. the porter brought me 2 letters - one from Mr Burton - Princeton - one from brother Aaron M.C. written the 6th [?] - says he thought sister H's Louise ought to go to her - that sister had but a little while to stay & Louise should have her company & counsel -- while she was able to enjoy & [?] & one from sister Mary - the same date - Answered brother A. that I had long felt that Louise should be sent to her mother -
entries.summaryText: Received letters from Mr Burton, brother Aaron M.C., and sister Mary regarding Louise's visit to her mother.

entries.fullText: Robinson - Ill- $25- Geo. W. Harper Left Vincennes at 4:45 A.M. after almost no sleep - got up & dressed at 3 & sat & looked & worried because I couldn't sleep - Trains & Engines crashing by almost constantly - Mr Harper met me at depot - rain pouring - Miss Mary [Buntin?] Ed. & Pub. of the Rural Republican - and Mrs Marion J. Zorn - a dry goods & notions merchant from Lawrenceville - Lawrence Co. Ill - came up to hear us - 20 minutes -
entries.summaryText: Traveled to Robinson, Illinois to meet with Geo. W. Harper and spoke to a small group including Miss Mary [Buntin?] and Mrs Marion J. Zorn.

entries.fullText:
Effingham Ill $25-
H.C. Painter
Left Robinson at 6.35 A.M.
but little good sleep--
breakfasted at Marshall--[reached?]
Effingham at 1 P.M.--Mr & Mrs
Painter & Mrs
Repler called at Etna
Hotel to [?]--cold &
cloudy--almost rain--very
muddy--about 100 in my
audience--the very best--all
50 & 75 cts--so the [?]
Mr Thompson, Painter
& paid expenses
Got letters here from sister Mary
brother Aaron had telegraphed brother
D.R. if they should send [?] to
Leavenworth--& he had replied
Hannah much the better [?]
in school--so I wrote Mary, Aaron
&Eugene--that I could not go
on lecturing unless [?] west--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her journey to Effingham, Illinois, where she gave a lecture to an audience of about 100 people. She also mentions receiving letters from her siblings and her decision to stop lecturing unless she goes west.

entries.fullText:
Veaga Ill.--$20-
J. Leyton F. Allison--
Left E. on 11 A.M.
freight train--stopped
with Mr Tracy RIngman &
Mrs Carrie Johnson Ringman--
Mrs. R. quite deaf--but a very
intelligent--Mrs W.J. Lemon
of Mattoon there to visit--
had a nice time--large
audience--two Postals
from Slayton begging me
to let him go on with my
engagements to first of May--
I feel that I ought to say
no on my own account, as well
as sister Hannahs--for I ametting dreadfully tired
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her journey to Veaga, Illinois, where she gave a lecture to a large audience. She also mentions receiving postcards from Slayton asking to continue her engagements until May, but she feels too tired to continue and decides to decline.

entries.fullText:
21,50
Nokomis - Ill - 2/3
H.F. White
Left Neoga at 8. A.M.
Mrs Lemon in company -
& dined with her at
Mattoon - then left M.
at 10. P.M. - reached
Nokomis at 3.30 -
first pleasant sun-
spring day for a week -
- Had small audience
they kept up high prices -
50 & 70 cts -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Neoga to Nokomis, Illinois, with H.F. White and dines with Mrs. Lemon in Mattoon. She arrives in Nokomis after a week of bad weather and has a small audience.

entries.fullText:
(Kansas - Ill - $30 -
W. W. Bishop - )
(thrown up - cause unknown)

Pana - Ill $25 -
D. J. Overshall
Dr T. H. McCoy
J. H. Southwich
[*Committee*]

Got only one
subscriber - a fearful
night - but cleared
my $25 - which will
help -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives only one subscriber in Pana, Illinois, but clears $25. She also mentions a previous stop in Kansas, Illinois, where she received $30 from W. W. Bishop before he threw up for an unknown reason.

entries.fullText:
Left Pana at 4 A.M. -
breakfasted at Decatur
& reached N. at noon -
- might just as well have
slept & come by way of
Matton by daylight - gifts
at 4 P.M. - Found
letters from sisters Hannah
& Mary - both saying Louise
was going to Leavenworth -
entries.summaryText: Traveling from Pana to Newman, received letters from sisters Hannah and Mary.

entries.fullText:
- Pemberton House -
- Thought to work at
Temperance speech for
the Powells church next
Sunday night - but couldn't
get at till I had cleared
up the letters - so wrote
over 20 in all - cleared
out all important ones -
- and did nothing
on my lecture - the
thought of speaking
in Chicago, again, is
simply appalling - but
I must just make a
simple plain talk on
Temperance [ext?] - or
else read my Purity lecture
entries.summaryText: Writing letters and preparing for a Temperance speech at the Powells church.

entries.fullText:
Train at 9 A.M. and
went to Decatur thence to
Peoria - arriving at 5 P.M. -
to hear and see Miss Helen
Potter - in her personatis
she gave [?], Charlotte
Cushman - A. E. Dickinson
& John B. Gough - she has
marvelous powers of
imitation - she had left
$100. for me with Dr Helen J. Underwood
at Blue Island - said it was
for S.B.A. personally - no society
no committee - no cause
but S.B.A.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Peoria to see Helen Potter perform and receives $100 from her.

entries.fullText:
Miss Potter left P. at 3 A.M.
insisted making me her guest at
Peoria Hotel - & paid my bill
with hers - she seems to me
what dear A.E.D. in the
olden days - before her alienation
by Mrs L's? story of my falseness to A.E.D.
- Have always felt that A.E. would
come to her senses & put away her
unjust feeling - Had a good
visit - Miss P. seems a very earnest
soul for equality for women -
I left at 8.41 = dined Fairley
& reached G. at 3.30 - - in
[?] of terrific thunder & lightning
hail, snow & finally rain
storm - but in spite of it - had
a fair audience - so the
com. paid all expenses - & 40 cts
over - stopped at City
Hotel - Mr Summer's -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with Helen Potter and reflects on her relationship with A.E.D. before traveling to Gibson and giving a speech.

entries.fullText: Had 2 hours at Farmers City depot- wrote long letter to Mrs. M [Folger?] trying to soothe her suspicions that I have not always been just to her in bringing her to the [?] or trying to - She is a dear good woman - but desperately misanthropic - distrusts everybody's loyalty to her & the truth Found letter from sister Mary - mailed Sat. 17th - saying she had seen niece Louisa snugly in sleeping car Friday night for Chicago - that she would leave there Tues A.M. - [?] if she got through all right landed her there this A.M. at 11 oclock - & what a joy to dear Sister Hannah's soul to have her only darling girl with her - it is a comfort to me to feel how happy H. must feel - nice visiting here- Mrs. Taylor & Mrs. Humphreys met me depot with carriage - slept at Mr. Arnolds - good bed & everything nice
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote a long letter to Mrs. M [Folger?] trying to soothe her suspicions. She found a letter from her sister Mary saying that her niece Louisa was in Chicago. She visited Leroy Ill and met with Mrs. Taylor and Mrs. Humphreys. She slept at Mr. Arnolds.

entries.fullText: Mrs Geo. H. Mentry the landlady & friend of Mrs H. M. I. Catters--had small audience--over a 100 though but Mr H. lacked $7 of cover expenses so I hand him [?] $[?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited Peru Ill and met with Mrs. Geo. H. Mentry. She had a small audience and gave Mr. H some money to cover expenses.

entries.fullText:
Left F. C.'s at 5 A.M. via Peoria
arrived at 10.30- stopped --
with Mrs Gillett -- a widow who
hosts boarders -- no letters here
- got telegram from Mattoon -- that
bundle was sent to Gilman &
ordered on to Chicago- cold
sleety & icy.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left F. C.'s at 5 A.M. via Peoria and arrived at 10.30- stopped with Mrs Gillett -- a widow who hosts boarders -- no letters here - got telegram from Mattoon -- that bundle was sent to Gilman & ordered on to Chicago- cold sleety & icy.

entries.fullText:
I. J. W. Harmon-
nice people-
Rev Augusta L. Chapin
preaches here --
Mrs Helen J. Underwood
M.D. -- Blue Island Ill --
& her younger sister-
a Dentist in this place
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met I. J. W. Harmon and Rev Augusta L. Chapin who preaches here, also met Mrs Helen J. Underwood M.D. and her younger sister who is a Dentist in this place in Blue Island.

entries.fullText:
$25
Rev. E. P. Powell
entries.summaryText: $25 Rev. E. P. Powell

entries.fullText:
$30
B. F. Shaw --
Small audience.
Mrs. H. E. Underwood
called on me -- The
landlady -- Mrs. Cheney
a woman suffragist --
entries.summaryText: $30 B. F. Shaw -- Small audience. Mrs. H. E. Underwood called on me -- The landlady -- Mrs. Cheney a woman suffragist --

entries.fullText:
Foreston [?] $30
C. E. Slocum
Peru - Ill 2/3
S. S. Booth
Stopped at Mr
Nascoms - had
fine audience
Mrs. J. McCormick
at lecture
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture in Foreston, with a fine audience including C. E. Slocum, S. S. Booth, Mr Nascoms, and Mrs. J. McCormick.

entries.fullText:
[?] Carroll $30
S. H. Lichty
stopped at the
ladies seminary here
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped at the ladies seminary in [?] Carroll.

entries.fullText:
Durand Ill - 2/3
Chas E. Griswold
Mrs Davis of Davis
came up to hear me - was at
the Teachers Con. at Troy, N. Y.
in 1857 - when I read my
essay on Educating the sexes together.
Mrs. J. R. Herrigy called [?]
Mrs Nancy G. [Herrig?] - 3 others
Mrs M. A. Butterfield
" Carrie M. Ashton
" May J. Ashton -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is visited by several women and a man in Durand, Illinois. They discuss a past conference in Troy, New York where Susan presented her essay on educating the sexes together.

entries.fullText:
Monroe Wis. $40.
Helen M. Bingham
Left Durand at 9 A.M.
Spent 4 hours at Beloit -
wrote 10 letters, ate dinner
- then spent 3 hours at
Hamover Junction - the
rain pourig
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Durand, Illinois to Monroe, Wisconsin with a stop in Beloit and Hamover Junction. She writes letters and eats dinner during her travels.

entries.fullText:
Left Monroe, Wis.,
Mr & Mrs. J. B. Teats at
2:20 A.M. reached Milwaukee
at 5 p.m. - went to Mrs.
Marion N. Dudley's - 290
Martin street- Sara Ford
Austin & Mary Stout Roddes
& daughter Mary called in eve'g -
also Mr. Chapman - the Premier
Merchant of M. employing over
100 women - & daughter Alice
called --- On way over
read letters rec'd at Monroe
one from nephew Frank of 27 & 28
saying that Dr. Peer had said of
Sister Hannah on Sunday the 25th
that he didn't think she could
live over six weeks - but might through
[?] summer - I telegraphed S. Clayton
to cancel all eight after Berlin [?] 4th
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Monroe, Wis to Milwaukee, visits Mrs. Marion N. Dudley and meets with several people. She also reads a letter about her sister Hannah's health.

entries.fullText:
Milwaukee Wis--$50
Chris E. Cruin
Mr. & Mrs. Stark & son & daughter
taking meals with Mrs. Dudley
Mr. Dudley preaching in the
Parker Memorial Hall--has
a call there--Got a letter
here from Mrs. Stanton--she
is at work in Ohio--& one
from brother D.R. written
a week ago to day--he has given
up all hope of sister Hannah's
recovery--but thinks she will
live this year--but that I
can do nothing but pass away many
hours--but that is a good deal--
so am glad I have thrown all up
--Easter Sunday--only 600 in
audience & my [?] not a bit
satisfactory--ought to have insisted
on giving my sound Purity lecture
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with Mrs. Dudley and receives letters from Mrs. Stanton and her brother D.R. She also attends Mr. Dudley's sermon and is dissatisfied with her own presentation.

entries.fullText: Left Mrs. Dudley's 7.30 & found A.M. train taken off-so was taken to Dr. Ross Wolcotts--spent day. took dinner, she took me to I. P.M. train--Mrs. Ross Wolcott gave me searching histories of several personage--sad chapters for poor woman nature--Stopped with Mrs. Maria L. Bracken--had five admirers--Cong. Minister Said no parallel between baby women & men--Received letters from sister written Saturday A.M. March 31st weak, trembly hand & with scalding tear drops over the paper--I can hardly visit to tell Berlin [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day with Mrs. Ross Wolcott and Mrs. Maria L. Bracken in Beaver Dam, Wisconsin. She receives letters from her sister.

entries.fullText: Left B. D. at 9 A.M. stopped at Commercial Hotel--Horicon till 5.40 P.M.--Tedious--tedious to have to wait & lose to night--No word yet from Slayton telling whether has obeyed my order to cancel all beyond Berlin--If I close with tomorrow night shall have sent the B.A. 200 subscribers c/2 enough to pay year's expenses --My [fratt?] receipts for the [11 1/2?] weeks--56 lectures--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day in Horicon and waits for news from Slayton about cancelling subscriptions beyond Berlin.

entries.fullText:
Splendid audience-
But oh what fearful
haste or hurry to be
done on my way
to my dear sister
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to a splendid audience in Berlin Wis and hurries to see her sister.

entries.fullText:
Left Berlin at
8 A.M. - & arrived
Chicago at 4 P.M.
Found Cousin
Melissa not well -
& Charlie poorly -
Wendell very well
- Saw Slayton &
paid him up all
his commissions - &
promised to fill arrg 'mts
from 16th to 21st
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Berlin to Chicago and visits family members, pays commissions, and makes arrangements for future plans.

entries.fullText:
Left Chicago - on
R Island RR at 10.15
A.M. -- Wendell went -
depot with him -- poor
boy -- how I did wish
it was best for him to
go along with me to see
his dear Mother
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Chicago on the R Island RR with Wendell.

entries.fullText:
Arrived at at
Leavenworth then
at 11.15 A.M.
brother D.R. met
me & rode up to sister
Hannahs with me --
Oh how feeble & yet
how bright & cheery
She met me -- was
not expecting me till
the 20th -- she can
barely walk across
the floor -- reports
herself better than for
some weeks
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived at Leavenworth and met with her brother D.R. and sister Hannahs who was not expecting her until the 20th. Hannahs is feeble but reports feeling better than she has in weeks.

entries.fullText: ? T. Harkrider engagements thrown up for all this week - that I might go to Sister Hannah
entries.summaryText: ? T. Harkrider engagements thrown up for all this week - that I might go to Sister Hannah

entries.fullText: Sister H seems stronger to day. Louise at Sister Annie's making calico dress
entries.summaryText: Sister H is feeling better and Louise is making a dress at Sister Annie's.

entries.fullText: Sister H seems brighter & stronger.
entries.summaryText: Sister H is feeling better and stronger.

entries.fullText:
Sister H. rode
out with brother
D.R. this noon -
about 1 P.M. - as
far as the Fort. Was
dreadful tired on
return -
entries.summaryText: Sister H. and brother D.R. rode to the Fort and Susan B. Anthony was tired on the return.

entries.fullText:
A. Leavenworth
with Sister Hannah
She rode with
Gilles to day - but
does not feel so
strong - is lame
in side - from
to long & fast ride
yesterday - she thinks
entries.summaryText: A. Leavenworth, Sister Hannah, and Gilles went for a ride but Sister Hannah is feeling weak and sore from the previous day's ride.

entries.fullText:
At Leavenworth
In P. M. Gilles
called for sister H
& she feeling not nearly
so strong as the few
days past--trembled &
tottered down the 20 steps
& into high buggy--but on
return she broke down
completely in getting off steps--
& so discouraged her - that
she feels she has made them
for the last time--& rode
for the last time also--
I was down town, else I
sure I could have saved her
from finding she had not strength
to accomplish the task - but she
has not felt so well since
She rode with D.R. Thursday. P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her sister H's health and how she rode for the last time due to her weakness.

entries.fullText:
Left Leavenworth [?]
on 4 P.M. R.J. train to
Cameron-thence St Jo & Hannibal
& C.B.& Q to Galena & Aledo--
Had but just got asleep
when at Brookfield--the Conductor
shouted Car broke down,--
all must get up & go into
rear car--& after the change
I went so fast asleep that I never
knew when we crossed Mississippi
& changed at Qu[?]--almost never
slept so soundly on cars before
The poor sad, sick face
of dear sister Hannah is before
me sleeping & waking--I fear
she may sink right down
on my leaving--it is too
cruel that I must go away
again--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her train journey from Leavenworth to Aledo and her concern for her sick sister Hannah.

entries.fullText:
Alledo- Ill $40
Prof. A. E. Frazier
arrived at 12- noon -
letter from Slayton saying
no engagements after 19th - which
rejoices me beyond words - for
every second the thought
of poor dear Sister Hannah
her groans & gasping for
breath - crowds upon me -
I long to fly back to her -
It was a man - here who
refused to let me off - Miss F.
& the ladies feel mortified at
the inhumanity of demanding $100
damages - Had fine audience -
Thunder shower just at close of lecture
over 50 women came 16 & 20 miles
to hear me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony talks about her lecture in Alledo, Illinois, and receiving a letter from Slayton. She expresses her concern for her sister Hannah and mentions the inhumanity of someone demanding $100 in damages.

entries.fullText:
Keithsburg Ill--$25
C. P. Burgetts--
Got Telegram Slayton to lecture
Greggsville Saturday night--Telegraphed
them impossible--Miss
Amanda E. Frazier--the
Mercer County Superintendent
Public Schools went to K. with
me--stopped at Mr Fred.
Burgetts
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about receiving a telegram from Slayton to lecture in Greggsville, which she had to decline. She also mentions traveling with Amanda E. Frazier and stopping at Mr. Fred Burgetts.

entries.fullText:
La Harpe IL $25
L. P. Coggswell

Miss [Frazer?] went
on steamer with me
to Burlington - I am
Daily there -

Terrible shower came
up at La Harpe - so
I did not go out to
lecture - Mr. Coggswell
told of Jos. Smith
& Mormon practices
at Nauvoo - before
the emigration to
Salt Lake
entries.summaryText: Miss [Frazer?] went on steamer with me to Burlington. Terrible shower came up at La Harpe. Mr. Coggswell told of Jos. Smith & Mormon practices at Nauvoo - before the emigration to Salt Lake.

entries.fullText:
Macomb. Ill $20
J. H. Franklin

Left Macomb on early train on C. B. & L. Miss Dumas & H. J. & Hanibal & Bansas CK - whole county flooded to almost a perpetual lake - reached Seaworth at 12 midnight brother D.R at train - went directly to Sister Hannah's - found her asleep -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Macomb to Seaworth, encountering flooded areas and arriving at her sister's house.

entries.fullText: With Sister Hannah - She has lost ground very perceptibly in the 5 days I have been gone - Said it seemed to her she could not have lived another day without me
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with her sister Hannah, who expresses how much she needs her.

entries.fullText:
With Sister Hannah
A most terrific
fever all day --
Jr Peer felt the
last change must
take place before
moving --
entries.summaryText: Sister Hannah and Jr Peer were present. Sister Hannah had a fever all day.

entries.fullText:
Sister Hannah
made desperate
effort & wrote letter
to Wendell to visit
her for a week --
also to sign
papers of propert[?]
securing $1000. To
her only daughter
Louise -- her effort
was wonderful
& her satisfaction
very great when all
was accomplished --
entries.summaryText: Sister Hannah wrote a letter to Wendell to visit her for a week and to sign papers of property securing $1000 to her only daughter Louise. Her effort was wonderful and her satisfaction very great when all was accomplished.

entries.fullText:
Wendell arrived
at noon this day - &
dear sister Hannah
was dressed & sitting
in her easy chair - &
with such a cheerful
face - she went out
to dinner with him -
but it was the last
time she had on
[wrapper- or went out
Now all but
Arthur were with - &
She felt ready to be
released fom her suffers
entries.summaryText: Hannah went out to dinner with Wendell, but it was the last time she went out. She felt ready to be released from her suffering.

entries.fullText:
A very cold
damp rainy day.
so neither brother D.R.
nor Annie called
I felt dear Hannah
was fast approaching her
last - still couldn't believe it
- she coughed seldom - &
raised none at all - until
about 5 P.M. - she sat up in
chair from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.
from 3 to 5 I tried to sleep
Came down & found the
death sweat had set in -
How could I go through with the
terrible scene--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a cold and rainy day in Leavenworth and her experience with Hannah's illness.

entries.fullText:
Dear Sister Hannah
breathed her last at 1200
midnight - & by 3. oclock
Sarah Louise & self had
bathed & dressed her for the
last time - Did not
send for Dan'l & Annie
until after daylight -
- when Dan'l came right
off before he ate breakfast.
-Sister A. purchases
the merino & lace - &
we did all ourselves
The coffin - metalic - with the
rosewood finish - very nice -
-I never realized that my
dear sister Hannah was
so beautiful - till now -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's sister Hannah passed away and they prepared her body for burial. They purchased a metallic coffin with a rosewood finish.

entries.fullText:
Brother Merritt
came at noon today--
& after dinner
came over to the
lone house on the hill
with brother D.--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's brother Merritt and brother D. visited her at the lone house on the hill.

entries.fullText: Sister Hannah's buried today - at 10 oclock - Rev Mrs. & Mrs. Page - Pres. made remarks, read from prayers & prayed - all very appropriate & grateful to all feelings - the day close & warm but did not rain while were going to Mt. Muncie--Where we left the dear lady that once moved & lived with & for us-- Brother Merritt took dinner with us--& slept at the desolate house--
entries.summaryText: Sister Hannah was buried in Leavenworth and Brother Merritt took dinner with us.

entries.fullText: Brother D. R. insisted I should not stop at the lone house another night--So Louise & I both went over to his house--leaving Eugene--Arthur Noah & Wendell --The hired girl Sarah Burke to get meals for them--& stay at her home nights
entries.summaryText: Susan and Louise went to Brother D. R.'s house while the children stayed with the hired girl, Sarah Burke.

entries.fullText:
At D.R.'s -
Brother Merritt
left for home
at 9 oclock A.M.
- carrying a nice
new Brussels
carpet that brother
D.R. gave him
Louise & self spent
day over at house
[?ing] & taking care
entries.summaryText: Brother Merritt left for home with a new carpet from brother D.R.'s. Louise and Susan spent the day at the house.

entries.fullText: Annie invited Eugene, Arthur, Frank & Wendell to dinner to day
entries.summaryText: Annie invited Eugene, Arthur, Frank & Wendell to dinner

entries.fullText: Visited Mt. Muncie this A.M. - it is a quiet spot
entries.summaryText: Visited Mt. Muncie, a quiet spot

entries.fullText:
Eugene & Frank
commenced boarding
at Mrs. Judge Latty's
to day.
Louise, Wendell
Lucy & Maud went
out to Mt. Muncie
this morning
entries.summaryText: Eugene and Frank started boarding at Mrs. Judge Latty's while Louise, Wendell, Lucy, and Maud went out to Mt. Muncie in the morning.

entries.fullText:
At Leavenworth
& at Brother
Daniel R's
Maud's 19th
birthday
entries.summaryText: Celebrating Maud's 19th birthday at Brother Daniel R's in Leavenworth.

entries.fullText: Mrs. Judge Norton- of Atchison came at 9 A M & spent day- Old school mate of Sister Annies at Pittsfield Mass they drove to fort in A. M. & took Louise- her first ride then- Wendell & Louise took 5 P. M. Rock Island train for Chicago- & now 6.30 P.M. alone in Sister Annies front chamber it seems like another burial of our dear sister Hannah- What a break up it is-- she was their chief stay & support-
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Judge Norton visits and goes on a ride with Sister Annies and Louise before leaving for Chicago.

entries.fullText: She was the chief stay and support.
entries.summaryText: No significant events mentioned.

entries.fullText: Very bright this A.M.--but at 2 P.M.-rainy again-a letter from M. Gage to day -telling of N.Y.W. S. meetings-I wrote her -& Mrs. Spencer- also Mrs Alida C. Ames -Penner- Col offering her to lecture from this point through September free, gratis & for nothing
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the weather and receiving a letter from M. Gage about N.Y.W. S. meetings. She also writes about writing to Mrs. Spencer, Mrs. Alida C. Ames, Penner, and Col offering a lecture from this point through September for free.

entries.fullText: Just 4 weeks to night at 12 Oclock- since dear sister Hannah passed out of her suffering body- it seems an age-- as many months as it is weeks- Letter from Louise today- saying Aunt A. E. wanted her to stay longer
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the passing of her sister Hannah four weeks ago and receiving a letter from Louise saying that Aunt A. E. wanted her to stay longer.

entries.fullText:
The Editors Convention
Capt. King & wife
Topeka[?] - & Judge
Horton & wife of
Atchinson stopped here
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the Editors Convention and people who stopped by.

entries.fullText:
Some 85 of the
Editors & wives - left
for Denver & Colorado
at 11 this A.M. brother
D.R. & Sister Annie in
company[?] - brother D.R.
the Pres. of their association
& the planner of trip
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the Editors Convention and the departure of some of the editors and their family members for Denver and Colorado.

people: Judge Horton & Wife & Col. John A. Martin & wife of Topeka
entries.fullText:
at L -
Brother J.R. & sister
A. returned at 6 P.M. -
Judge Horton & Wife &
Col. John A. Martin &
wife of Topeka stopped
to tea - 40 minutes - J.R.
telegraphed they would
had Strawberries - [?] and
oranges, bananas- [?]-
butter -& splendid coffee--
- & all [promised?] all go out
entries.summaryText: Brother J.R. & sister A. returned, Judge Horton & Wife & Col. John A. Martin & wife of Topeka stopped to tea.

entries.fullText: at L -
entries.summaryText: At L.

entries.fullText:
Gilles drove out to
Mt. Muneire- Lucy
E & Susie D went
with me-the cemetery
seemed so restful-
& dear Hannah's
two months ago tired
so tired body rests there
-but oh so alone- so
away from the spot where
rest the bodies of her
loved father & sister Guelma--
but I must give it up &
say farewell even to the spot
that covers the last of her
mortal past- & the other is it
where & how-that no
question!!
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits a cemetery with Gilles, Lucy E, and Susie D. She reflects on the resting place of Hannah, who is buried away from her loved ones.

entries.fullText:
Left- Leavenworth at
5 P.M. on R. l. Train for
Rochester- N. Y.
had to wait at Cameron
until 1 O'clock A.M.-
before the H. & St. Jo. train
came-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Leavenworth for Rochester, NY, but has to wait in Cameron for the H. & St. Jo. train.

entries.fullText:
Reached Quincy at
10 A.M. --failed
to connect -- took
carriage to Mrs
Sarah Denman's
903 Broadway -- Mrs
Mary C. Gilpin called --
lives across the street --
corner of 9th st & Broadway
Mrs Sarah Dwight-King
of Jacksonville - Ill - was
visiting Mrs Denman - &
accompanied me this far
at 5 P.M. ---
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Quincy and visited Mrs. Sarah Denman, Mrs. Mary C. Gilpin, and Mrs. Sarah Dwight-King.

entries.fullText:
On Toledo, Wabash
& Western R.R. -- reached
Toledo at 9.20 -- took
carriage to see Mrs
S. L. Williams & staid
until 6 P.M. -- then
train for home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited Mrs. S. L. Williams in Toledo before returning home.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Buffalo at
4 A.M. - at 7 A.M.
took carriage to cousin-
Geo. Vails . 31 Irving Place
-- no one up -- so
walked about for an
hour or so - had
pleasant visit - &
at 2 P.M. Geo took
me to train - & reached
home 4.25 found
niece Louise at depot
& mother & Mary &
Aaron all as usual
at no 7
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Buffalo, visited her cousin Geo. Vails, and returned home to find her niece Louise and family.

entries.fullText:
At Home
Lottie B. Anthony
wife of Asa
Anthony's son
Daniel M. - he's
very low -- --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home and visited Lottie B. Anthony, the wife of Asa Anthony's son Daniel M. who was very ill.

entries.fullText: All of this week broken up with trying. do something hard the dear Dottie -in her terrible sufferings-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her week and mentions Dottie's suffering.

entries.fullText:
At Home
Louise & I went to Unitarian Church. Mr Mann's last sermon till September-knew but very few of the people - [?] as [?] a
stranger in Rochester as in Chicago New York or Leavenworth
Called [with?] Mary & William Hallowells in P.M. & on return called to see how Lottie was- & found her [?} the card-He ceased breathing at 4 oclock- a blessed rest from untold suffering but such a world of care
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending church and visiting friends. She also mentions the death of someone named Lottie.

entries.fullText:
left for somebody else
- four children -
one 9 - one 5 - and twins
9 months -
Lottie is the 4th
of our 15 women voters
who have gone home
Rhoda De Gormo &
Sister Guelma & Hannah
making the other three
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Lottie, the 4th of 15 women voters who have gone home, and mentions Rhoda De Gormo, Sister Guelma, and Hannah.

entries.fullText: Lottie B. Anthony was buried at 2 P.M. - large funeral - & old time talk by an old gentleman Mr Norton - who had worked with her in Temperance - Georgianne B. Purvis Daughter of Robert Purvis, & sister of Harriet Purvis this day - from Consumption she has been a long sufferer
entries.summaryText: Lottie B. Anthony was buried and there was a large funeral. An old gentleman named Mr. Norton spoke about her work in Temperance. Georgianne B. Purvis, daughter of Robert Purvis and sister of Harriet Purvis, passed away from consumption after a long illness.

entries.fullText:
At Home- Rochester
This is the 60th anniversary
of the marriage of our dear
Father & Mother- Father died
5 years before their 50th & Mother
has live 10 years since their 50th
and is very comfortable- though
feeble -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the 60th anniversary of her parents' marriage.

entries.fullText:
at Home
Letters from Merritts
Lucy & from Eugene
& Frank Mosher -
sent $50. to Mr
Slayton to do extra advertising
work for me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about receiving letters and sending money for advertising work.

entries.fullText: At Home
entries.summaryText: At Home

entries.fullText:
At Home
Sister Mary started
for Kansas- to [stop at
Detroit & Chicago on way
Mother takes Marys
departure more
cheerfully than she
did last October
when M. went to the to Centennial
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary started for Kansas with stops in Detroit and Chicago. Mother takes Mary's departure more cheerfully than last year's departure to the Centennial.

entries.fullText:
Went down town
with Louise & bought
a croquet sett for
her-

Leavenworth Times
this date- tells of a
registered letter from Oskaloosa said to contain
$891-being lost or stolen
from bother D.R.'s Post Office
- it was receipted for by
brother Eugene-recorded
on the local books by
nephew Frank & handed
to Major Sternes the head
clerk of money Department-
entries.summaryText: Went shopping with Louise and bought a croquet set. The Leavenworth Times reports on a lost or stolen registered letter containing $891 from D.R.'s Post Office, which was receipted for by Eugene, recorded on local books by Frank, and handed to Major Sternes.

entries.fullText:
Sent letters to sundry
persons to see proof of
Con & Officers of N.W.S..A.
entries.summaryText: Sent letters to various people to see proof of Con and Officers of N.W.S..A.

entries.fullText: Got letter from Nephew Frank, written the 27th saying the mystery of the stolen letter remained unravelled -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from her nephew Frank on July 31, 1877, in which he stated that the mystery of the stolen letter remained unsolved.

entries.fullText:
Went to Dr. Reyner -
he filled my left
side front tooth with soft-filling
- but I am very doubtful of it
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Dr. Reyner to fill her left side front tooth with soft-filling, but she is doubtful of it.

entries.fullText:
Aunt Amy Read's &
Uncle Joseph Howe's daughter
Elvira Howe Bushenell - of
Phelps, Ontario Co - died at
8 o'clock this evening - aged 76.
Julia Wilborn of Washington
called here an hour --
entries.summaryText: Elvira Howe Bushenell died at the age of 76 in Phelps, Ontario Co. Julia Wilborn of Washington visited.

entries.fullText:
Called at William
Hallowells in P.M. &
visited them with Julia
Wilborn
entries.summaryText: Visited William Hallowell with Julia Wilborn.

entries.fullText:
Postal came from
Cousin Lucius Howe
tells of death of
Sister Bushnell
entries.summaryText: Cousin Lucius Howe informs of the death of Sister Bushnell.

entries.fullText:
Niece Maggie & her
little Julie - 2 yrs old the 8th of this
months - spent day at no.7 - very
sweet & pleasant -
A Postal from Cousin
Lucius Howe - saying Almira
Bushnell died Saturday & funeral
take place Wednesday tomorrow -
A letter from Sister Mary
saying she had decided to
bring brother Merritts Daniel
aged 12 yrs - home with her to
go to school
entries.summaryText: Niece Maggie and her daughter Julie visit. Cousin Lucius Howe informs of the death of Almira Bushnell and Sister Mary decides to bring her brother Merritts Daniel home to go to school.

entries.fullText: Took 7.25 train for Phelps - lovely morning - arrived there 9.30 - funeral of Cousin Elmira House Bushnell at 10:30 - found her sister - Cousin Nancy Clark had been with her ten days - previous to her death - Mr Martin Alice Bushnell's husband was there - she has been dead 6 years - & he not remarried - Mary D. Farly a sister of Alice - & a widow for years has - Farley House & wife - & Mrs Loring son [?] of Thomas House there - from Waterloo - I staid till 6 P.M. - got home at 8 - dear mother said I didn't know how to let you go - but she got on all right - says she breaths shorter & shorter each day -
entries.summaryText: Attended the funeral of Cousin Elmira House Bushnell in Phelps and spent time with family and friends until 6 P.M.

entries.fullText: Sister May returned home - bringing with her brother Merritt's son Daniel
entries.summaryText: Sister May returned home with Merritt's son Daniel.

entries.fullText: Went to Unitarian Church, taking niece Louise Mosher & nephew Daniel L. Anthony brother Merritts son -- & got them installed in the Sunday School -- Mr Mann preached one of his best sermons on the two religions -- one of forms & ceremonies The other of education & teaching -- Danni doing very nicely so far -- I do hope he will continue to & be a comfort to sister M
entries.summaryText: Susan went to church with her niece and nephew and got them installed in Sunday School. She listened to a sermon on two religions and was pleased with how her nephew was doing.

entries.fullText: Made last call on Dr Allen - he has made total failure of my plate for front tooth. It costs me more annoyance than all my teeth together for all my life. So difficult to get one that does not interrupt full enunciation of my words. -Mary & William Hallowell called this eve - also Mrs Rogers & husband Buell - (A most marked change in brother Aaron's manifestations of kindly acts & words toward all of us in home of late.)
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Dr. Allen and complains about her plate for her front tooth. She also mentions visits from Mary, William, Mrs. Rogers, Buell, and her brother Aaron.

entries.fullText: John Williams Mrs. Colman & Gertrude accompanied me to S. & left Rochester at 3.20 P.M.--brother Aaron forgot to order express man so had no good gown to speak in at S. Got baggage man to check it for me-- so I should find it on arrival at Lockport-- It was sad enough to part with dear mother - so calm & serene almost 84 - the feeling that I was taking my last look last kiss last hand shake would prevail-- Stopped at Mrs Budgebys, Mrs Edwin Arnold - Mrs. Cynthia Dutcher good people splendid audience. [?] & Catherine Miller called this A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Somerset, Niagra Co, N.Y. with John Williams, Mrs. Colman, and Gertrude. She mentions forgetting her gown and having to check it with the baggage man. She also mentions stopping at Mrs Budgebys, Mrs Edwin Arnold, and Mrs. Cynthia Dutcher's homes and receiving a good reception. Lastly, she mentions a visit from [?] and Catherine Miller in the morning.

entries.fullText: Took stage at 7 A. M. at Somersett -- & drove 18 miles on to Lockport -- & a [lovely?] ride it was found Mrs. Cushing's home pleasant -- had a fine audience of 600 - in new Opera House -- gave [Back?] the Ballot - pretty well -- throat sore troublesome -- though better -- she invited Messrs Brockett -- Atwater -- James W. Reid, -- Mr Richardson [?] Ed. Journal & sundry others to a lunch at her house after the lecture -- I took the train at 12.30 midnight for Detroit -- Sarah
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a stage to Lockport, NY and gave a lecture on 'Back the Ballot' to an audience of 600 people in a new Opera House. She had a sore throat but it was getting better. She was invited to a lunch at Mrs. Cushing's house after the lecture.

entries.fullText: Arrived Detroit 10 A.M. stopped Russell House till 2.15 P.M. Wrote A. J. Johnson & returned his check for $21.70 - to send me copy of his Cyclopedia with bill for balance - Found Mrs. Williams at Depot - had splendid audience in White's Hall - mostly the working men -& they gave most attentive responsive hearing. left on the 12 midnight train for Chicago -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Detroit and wrote a letter to A. J. Johnson. She gave a lecture to a splendid audience of mostly working men in White's Hall and left for Chicago on the 12 midnight train.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Chicago at 8 A.M.
found nephew Wendell at Depot -
went round to Aunt Ann Eliza
Dickinson's & had good breakfast
& short chat - & then back to
Depot & off for Leavenworth
at 10.15 - - Wendell gets some
side thrusts from Cousin Melissa
about not being prompt & accurate
in his way of figuring - it is too
bad that older people & heads of
business do not feel & speak more
tenderly to young persons - but
poor Melissa is overworked &
half-sick all the time - & so
I told Wendell - & that he must
lay her looks nor words to heart -
only to be sure he did not
do his work slip-shod so as to
deserve them -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Chicago and had breakfast with her nephew and Aunt Ann Eliza Dickinson before leaving for Leavenworth. Cousin Melissa criticized Wendell's work but Susan advised him not to take it to heart.

entries.fullText:
On [?.?.] train -
was wakened at 4.30 -
to find that we must all
transfer around a broken
bridge - just east of Fairfield Ill. -
broken by feight train - and
that we were to reach Leavenworth
7 hours late - 6 P.M. instead of 11. A.M.
Found Mr Crosby - next
door neighbor to brother D.R.
on board - he gave me his
birth in the center part of sleeper -
- no one expected me until tomorrow -
found Eugene in the
{?] O. - & D. R. in Editors room up stairs
- all well but Insie B. - & she
down with chills & fever - &
Maud, too, sort of blue
& shivery round the house.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's train was delayed due to a broken bridge and she arrived in Leavenworth 7 hours late. She found Mr. Crosby on board and visited with family members, but Insie B. was sick with chills and fever and Maud was feeling blue and shivery.

entries.fullText: At Leavenworth - Rev [Mr?] L.G. Terry. the stage and Omnibus proprietor for 20 years here - was buried this P.M. -- Mrs Terry left alone- not a child - they were nearest neighbors to brother J.R. in 1865 - Eugene called in A.M & spent the time till nearly 1 P.M. - & after dinner both Frank & Eugene called --no clue yet to the last registered letter -- but circumstantial evidence seems resting down against Major Shreves - but I do hope some other theory for its loss will be proved - It rained nearly all day - [Little?] susie bright & [sweet?] until late in the P.M. - then high fever came on-
entries.summaryText: Rev L.G. Terry was buried, Eugene and Frank visited, and Little Susie fell ill.

entries.fullText: Left - Leavenworth - Kan - at 8.45 A.M. for Colorado to begin canvass there for women suffrage - tomorrow night - Brother Eugene gave me his note from April 14 1877 - for the $600. Sister Hannah had of me during her sojourn in Kansas & Colorado from Jan .[?d] 1876 - to May 11th 1877 - - Little Susie B. quite ill with chills & fever - a terrible disease it is - Maud not looking well either - all three were attacked with the disease just a year ago now - & I fear all will be [worse?] Annie seemed pleasant but not as bird-like as most always. At Granada [?]- a young man - L.R. Dyer - Fort Elliot - Texas took [copy? trial?] & gave me $10. - he is a Cattle dealer --
entries.summaryText: Susan left Leavenworth for Colorado, received a note from Eugene, and Little Susie fell ill again. She also met L.R. Dyer, a cattle dealer, in Granada.

entries.fullText: Spoke in R.R. Station waiting roo-perhaps 15 voters, 10 women-20 or 30 boys, girls & [?] [?] outlook from first meeting-they had never heard a lecture-seen a tract or newspaper or [?} & this one lecture can do very little toward lifting the men out of all the traditional & educational feelings & prejudices -Staffed at C.B. Crittenden's- two daughters Ida & Clara - do all work 8.10,17 at meals-mother, [?] M. Critendene is east on a visit at Topeka-dined at F. C. Brown's - a rancher one mile down the line - Arkansas his partners T. B. Beals - daughter is wife of Browns son-an intelligent young woman. T.B. Nolan is the P.M. Mrs Mary A. Jones-the teacher-W W. Jones - Mr-Sowden bought back trial
entries.summaryText: Spoke to a group at the R.R. Station waiting room, had dinner at F. C. Brown's ranch, and met several people including T.B. Beals and Mary A. Jones.

entries.fullText: Maonic Hall- Mrs Helen Lane Weaver Teacher Mrs G M Woodworth Charles W Bowman-Ed. Leader Mrs Harrient Mercer of this [?] left husband-washes & supports three children- Mrs Woodworth is sister of the Monroe of Mrs Monroe of Atchison Kans-She took me on drive to Kit Carson's home - Habb Town-Mrs Carson's children live there with Mr Robb her brother- Mr John Prowers & the wealthiest [?] - kind & full breed Indian- Mr Prowers is school director
entries.summaryText: Visited Maonic Hall and met several people including Helen Lane Weaver, G M Woodworth, Charles W Bowman, and John Prowers, the wealthiest and kindest full breed Indian.

entries.fullText:
Hon. W. F.Stone
Shaffer
Sanderson
Hughes -
Stopped at Lindell Hotel -
found not notice in papers or
posters- no hall engaged- &
nobody knowing of my coming -
had bills printed & had a full
house - Chilicott Hall - Mr
Hughes introduced me - he
is large Lumberman - loud
audience - or many hogs were
Lucy Stone did not give any
notice of my coming at her
meeting the week before —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived at Pueblo, Colorado and found no notice of her coming in the papers or posters. She had bills printed and had a full house at Chilicott Hall. Lucy Stone did not give any notice of her coming at her meeting the week before.

entries.fullText:
[Judge] Fred, Walsen -
wife Emma Sporleder married
ten years - 2 children - nice house
x Cottonwood trees around it - he
is the oldest settler - & main man
of the town - stopped at his father
in law's hotel - August Sporleders -
- made very comfortable - apples
10 cts a lb. here - potatoes 2 1/2 -
met here C. W. Wilson
of Austin - Texas - Reportedly
opposed to woman suffrage
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived at Walsenburg, Colorado and stayed at August Sporleders. She met with Fred Walsen and his wife Emma Sporleder. She also met C. W. Wilson of Austin, Texas who was reportedly opposed to woman suffrage.

entries.fullText:
W. L. Leonard
Mr L. gone - stopped at
New State Hotel- the proprietor
gave me his Ginny room -
reached [there?] at 7.30 - after
tedious waiting & horrible
dinner at Cucharas-

and haunted me all the
day -
It was this night
at the [??tes] hotel that I dreamed
of seeing my Father - 11 years dead -
a haggard looking wrech
from drinking - it was too horrible
entries.summaryText: Stayed at New State Hotel in El Moro and had a bad dinner at Cucharas. Had a nightmare about her father.

people:
Col. J.H. Rice-Ed. Enterprize &
Geo. R. Swallow
entries.fullText:
Col. J.H. Rice-Ed. Enterprize &
Geo. R. Swallow - stopped with -
everything in beautiful order
& excellent tea & coffee - first
"Christian" cup of coffee since
I left brother D.R's--
at about 11 A.M. on arrival
in hack from [Elure?]- Mr
Sturgis stopped me - & gave
nice letter from sister Mary
my first word since I left -
Letter from Mr Richards the
Ph[?] ex. com. at Denver -
wretched writing & spelling--
Wrote letters to sister Mary,
Mrs Stanton - A.J. Johnson etc.
met here Mrs Archibald & her
son Edwin of Kansas -
entries.summaryText: Stayed with Col. J.H. Rice-Ed. Enterprize & Geo. R. Swallow in Trinidad and received a letter from sister Mary and Mr Richards. Met Mrs Archibald and her son Edwin of Kansas.

entries.fullText: Had tedious 5 hours waiting at Cucharas station-- nice lunch of Mrs Swallows -splendid ride through the La Veta Pass-highest point 9.300 feet above level of sea - around south [?] of the Sierra Blanca--highest peak of Col. reached G. at 7.50 - had Mr Gene McCoy newest hotel drawing room - & large audience -- nobody seemed to know [or] care anything about the cause. Mr Thomas not at home- Col. Holigsworth with several others came over from the Fort.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a tedious wait at Cucharas station, had lunch with Mrs. Swallows, and had a splendid ride through the La Veta Pass. She reached G. at 7.50 and had a large audience, but nobody seemed to care about the cause.

entries.fullText: Took stage at six A.M - Mr Lorenzo Dow - of the Silverton Mines - on board - a pleasant & intelligent man - also Mr Hally - of Chieftian notoriety - very shallow - opposed - One vast bed of [?] inland sea - evidently - entirely surrounded by majestic mountain ranges - the Raton, main [large?], Cochetope, & Sangre Christo - 65 miles across - reached De Norte at 5 P.M. - stopped at M. W. Richardson's - Mr Deeker had packed M.E. Church & on [?ohid] "age" note
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a stagecoach with Mr. Lorenzo Dow and Mr. Hally. She saw a vast bed of inland sea surrounded by majestic mountain ranges. She reached De Norte at 5 P.M. and stopped at M. W. Richardson's.

entries.fullText:
Spend day at Mrs Richardson
Mr R. & Mr Foster started for
Ouray in P.M.
Took tea at Rev --A. M. Darley
and stage for Lake at
7 P.M. - and it was joy
joy all night long - at
midnight, at Wagon Wheel
Gap I got out & went
down to Rio Grand & drank
of it's clear icy waters.
Scenery magnificent
& night equaly so - bright
moon --but had to sit
inside too cold to be out
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at Mrs. Richardson's and then travels to Lake, stopping at Ouray and Wagon Wheel Gap. She drinks from the Rio Grand and describes the scenery.

entries.fullText:
Lake City--Col-
G.F. Lee--(H.C. Olney)
Henry C. Olney is Editor of
The Sliver World--& Mrs. O. invites
me to stop with her--
reached Lake at 1. P.M.
after a stage ride of
18 hours--found Mrs. O.
a genuine woman--graduate
from Cornell College--Iowa--
her sister Mrs Harris & daughter with her
--An immense audience--The
Court House too small--fully 1000
or 1500 stood on ground in front--
& I on Court House steps top of a dry
goods box--a very enthusiastic
meeting & large [wagerity?]
"age" note
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives at Lake City and is invited to stay with Mrs. O. She speaks to an enthusiastic audience of 1000-1500 people at the Court House.

entries.fullText:
Found it impossible to go
to Ouray- it is 50 miles over
the mountain & most dangerous
trail & 125 round it with
no possible way but private
carriage-which would take
full 3 days. So spent day at
Mrs Olneys -Mrs S.N. Wood of
Kansas lives here-Mr. W. not
at home- meeting for organization
this evening at C.H. --house full & I
answered the objections.
It was this morning that dear
mother slipped from her chair
to the floor & gave her great
shock-so Mary was alarmed-
It does seem too cruel for me to be gone
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her inability to go to Ouray and spending the day at Mrs. Olneys. She also mentions a meeting for organization and her mother's health.

entries.fullText:
Left Lake City at 6 A.M.
wound round the mountain
sides down the Gunnison River
for 21 miles - a most rugged
mountain grade-- then turned
east up Indian & Beaver
Creeks - & reached Ft.
Sanderson at 5 P.M. - where
the landlady soon informed
me she didn't women to vote-
a silly, weak woman - & a
wretched cook & house keeper
- Her husband Mont.
Hill believes in suffrage
