& will vote yes - so let
the weak wife go -
met at Hills - Capt. Hays - an
Englishman who will vote
no -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Lake City to Ft. Sanderson and meets with Mont. Hill and Capt. Hays, discussing their views on suffrage.

entries.fullText: Left Fort Sannderson-Mont.[?] at 7 A.M. & sped on over mountain & through Canon-crossed the Cochetope Pass over into the Saguache Valley & at top of the Cochetopa Mountain-the waters divide -start but a few feet apart- one little rivulet for the Pacific another for the Atlantic -Dined at Mrs Mary C. Ellis a beautifully cultured woman-wants to vote & very thing neat & clean & well cookery-husband going to vote "no"-reached Saguache at 8 P.M.-not a letter here - fully expected something from home-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Fort Sannderson-Mont. to Saguache Valley, dines with Mrs. Mary C. Ellis, and arrives at Saguache without receiving any letters.

entries.fullText: Hon W.B Felton called early t his A.M. & I called on his wife last evening - both believe in suffrage- Had Court House packed & Mrs Shelton said you made an argument- Lucy Stone's was on appeal- stopped at the Gibbs house- got letter here from Dr Avery regretting I could not fill the Ouray apt. of Committee--I could have done so if the Com. had known what the geography of this section
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Hon W.B Felton and his wife, attends a court hearing, and receives a letter from Dr Avery about the Ouray apt. of Committee.

entries.fullText:
South Arkansas - Col
rode 48 miles through the
Poncha Pass-named for
Puncho[?] the Indian ch[?] for [?]
reached S.A. at 6 A.M and
was just about done for-
Stopped at James True's-
his wife died last spring-
first time I ever slept in a
house where there was no
woman but myself-had
a man cook-his father in law-
Wilson & his brother Cha[?]
True were his family.
Mr T then insisted I should
turn north & leave the six
Southern aff's of the Com-& I
decided to do so-Mrs. Loella
Bule to go with us
Got letter here from sister May Sept 16th
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels through South Arkansas, stays at James True's house, and decides to turn north.

entries.fullText:
Texas Creek - Col
[Mr. R. Egglestone]
Mr James True-Ward
his brother & Miss Loella
Bale-started with me for
California gulch mines- [?]
of gray horses & Spring Buggy
Dined at Brown's Creek at
Mr Evans - and spoke at
Helena-P.M. Westons
new & nice stone house--spoke
in School House --Rev. Mr Adams
there (English) on the fence
was dreadfully discouraged
feared I had made an awful
blunder -turning northward-
still all [?] friend deemed
it best-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to California gulch mines and speaks at various locations in Texas Creek, despite feeling discouraged about turning northward.

entries.fullText:
Ula - Col
J.M.. Davis
Reignald Sweetland
Granite -Col-
Mr. Hemp with his own
black ponies & Mr True's
carriage took us from
Helena & the True returned
home- Stopped with
Mr & Mrs F.E. Hagden - & spoke
in their Bar-room to 30 men
guess I mad several votes here
entries.summaryText: Spoke to men in a bar-room and made several votes.

entries.fullText:
Rosita-Col
George G. Adams
H.G. Dickinson
Oro City-Col
Left Granite at 9 & reached
Oro at 9 P.M. 23 miles
--are Odd Fellow's Ball here
--nevertheless- I spoke to
70 or 100 voters in J.W.
McDermith's Saloon --&
slept at Mrs Alexander's-- the
nominee for School Superintendent-
Gov. Routt was present & gave
his vote or side of W.S.
Capt. S.D. Bruse-& Rob. Berry
entries.summaryText: Spoke to voters in a saloon and slept at Mrs Alexander's.

entries.fullText:
Mr. Tabor took me down
from Oro - Mr & Mrs. Alexander
& Miss Wilmer with us -
spoke in Wm Nyes Saloon -
packed with Standing men -
made a good speech -
but alas - such numbers
of Irish Catholics - might
as well pour water on a Ducks
back - as present arguments to such
Couldn't get a place to sleep in
town - so rode down to [Molton?]
4 miles - & stopped Rahrer's Hotel -
the dirtiest bed & hardest side
of a plank at that
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks in Leadville, Colorado, but faces opposition from Irish Catholics and has trouble finding a place to sleep.

entries.fullText:
Left [Molton?] at 8 A.M.
spring wagon - 45 miles to
Fair Play - stopping only to take
lunch at foot of mountains -
& at F. P. got fresh pair of
Horses - & Dr. Lewis drove
me over to Alma - 6 miles
- was too giddy to stand or walk
- rested on bed a few minutes
[cleaned?] took cup of coffee
& at 7 went to Court House
to find the largest crowd ever
seen in Alma - returned to
Fair Play after lecture - but
a [?] bed -once more-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Alma, Colorado to give a lecture and faces a large crowd at the Court House.

entries.fullText: Stopped at Killdufs Hotel- large audience-Judge Henry introduced me-The Dem. Editor got out bills announcing "Free Love" to night friends got up protest signed by all best men & women & Judge Henry presented resolution against which has carried with a well-- Got solid aye from both men & women-as to giving working women equal chances
entries.summaryText: Introduced by Judge Henry at Killdufs Hotel to a large audience. Protest signed against the announcement of "Free Love" and resolution presented in favor of giving working women equal chances.

entries.fullText: Left Fair Play at 6 A.M.--rode on outside of stage all day-84 miles to Morrison-where dear sister Hannah boarded last Sept & left for Kansas the 1st of Oct--a year ago- Can it be that she is gone from us forever - her presence is continual with me as I near Denver. Stopped at Grand Central -tired enough-my ride through Turkey Creek Cannon in the dark--was most exciting-
entries.summaryText: Traveled from Fair Play to Morrison and thought about her sister Hannah who left for Kansas a year ago. Stayed at Grand Central and had an exciting ride through Turkey Creek Cannon in the dark.

entries.fullText:
Miss Hindman - the
first to call on me--
Mrs Ball of Kansas--then
Mr Clark whose wife
dear Sister Hannah so
loved where here--then
cousin Webster Anthony
at whose house Sister Hannah
enjoyed her visits so much.
-called at Mr David M.,
Richards Book Store & met
on street Dr. Alida C Avery.
Who offered her guest chamber
while I stopped in Denver which
I accepted & Miss Hindman
confirmed round after tea - & also
called with me on Mrs Abby Sage
Richardson -Letters from home--
Dear Mother had had another
fall & was very much [?]--but [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives visitors, accepts an offer for a guest chamber, and visits Mrs. Abby Sage Richardson.

entries.fullText:
Letter from Mr & Mrs Israel Hall
of Ann Arbor -deeding to me 320
acres good land & well timbered in the
county of St. Francis Arkansas--
as a tribute to my life work for women
--specially moved by my coming to Colorado
without promise of pay-
Dr Avery left for the east
this A.M. [?] W.P. her
home is very delightful - may
it inspire me to write my
promised new lecture on
"Homes of Single Women"
Went with Miss Hindeman to
hear Abby Sage Richardson's lecture
on Shakespeare-it was good-
but such a waste of time & talent
to be digging among dead men all the
time.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a tribute of land, Dr. Avery leaves, and Susan attends a lecture on Shakespeare.

entries.fullText:
got letter from Mrs M. T. Adams
Maniton inviting me to visit her
Box from Mrs Stanton - containing
History pamphlet with her Dinner
speech - cost $7.80 - just like
her knowledge of the cost of things
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Mrs M. T. Adams inviting me to visit her in Maniton and a box from Mrs Stanton containing a history pamphlet with her dinner speech.

entries.fullText:
Dinner - Dr. Averys
Mrs. Abby Gage Richardson
called - doesn't seem to
take any interest in
living things - dwells
wholly in literary matters
of the past - Doesn't read
newspapers -
entries.summaryText: Dinner with Dr. Averys and visit from Mrs. Abby Gage Richardson who seems uninterested in current events.

entries.fullText:
Dinner - Dr Averys
Writing speech
Houses of Single Women
entries.summaryText: Dinner with Dr. Averys and writing a speech about Houses of Single Women.

entries.fullText: went to hear Mrs Margaret W. Campbell lecture - on the lesson of the Election - 2 to 1 - against suffrage - fair audience & fair speech - though not fluently spoken- . Dined with Miss Hindman at Mrs Sheriffs -
entries.summaryText: Attended a lecture by Mrs Margaret W. Campbell on the lesson of the Election and had dinner with Miss Hindman at Mrs Sheriffs.

entries.fullText: Denver lecture - $100 H.A. Cofield - in Menecher Hall - Price 75 cts nothing lower - perfect sacrifice of me - about 100 present- could not get over the feeling that I had been victimized to the greed of the managers - but made a tolerable speech - though stiff & strained in manner - Miss Hindman dined with me at Mrs Simms. Took the $100 as [severely?] as Shilock did his pound of flesh- not a line from home since that of 24th Sept - am really worried bet mothers [?] much worse - but will take [?]
entries.summaryText: Gave a lecture in Denver and received $100. Had dinner with Miss Hindman at Mrs Simms. Worried about mother's health.

entries.fullText:
Left Denver at 4 P.M.
for Boulder - had [pleasant?]
R.R. ride out to the foot of
the foot hills
Mrs North of Boulder
Mr Wright - the Pres of
B. Co. W. S. Society introduced
me - large proportion of
men at my lecture - all
said the strongest, ablest
argument they had heard
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Boulder and gives a lecture with a strong argument that is well received by a large proportion of men in attendance.

entries.fullText:
[Denver - Col - $100
H.A. Cofield - Manager -]
Woman wants bread, not the Ballot
Boulder - Col
Mrs Phebe Mrs. Kelsey &
her daughter Mary - [?]
Mr Braniard's Boulder Home
in A.M. called on Mrs
[Arndt?] Mrs Jane Greberg [ ?]
Sister - & who took dear sister
Hannah through Boulder [???]
last June - a year ago [???]
she seemed to enjoy it very much
& after trip to Cannon & back
28 miles - we took train & back
to Denver to meet brother D.R. &
Sister Annie at the American Hotel
Heavy rain at 4 P.M. & all
evening. still a good audience -
a splendid compliment to me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with various women in Boulder and then travels to Denver to meet with family, despite heavy rain there is still a good audience at her lecture.

entries.fullText:
[*raining all day*]
Left Boulder at 3 P.M.
for Denver - rained all day
- Mrs Mary G. Arnett was
to take me to Boulder Canon
this A.M. - but alas - the storm
- first in five months - I
anticipated so much "joy of
[Ladoress?]" in going over same
ground that sister H. did &
with the same person -
- was guest of Mr & Mrs [Per??]
of the Boulder Hotel - went
round & lunched with Mrs Kelsey
& daughter Mary - Mrs E.A.V.
Stone - Book store merchant -
called on me to tell me Mrs
Stantons Leg. address of 1854 had
been the guiding star of her life.
- many good people at Boulder
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Boulder to Denver, encountering rain and meeting various people along the way.

entries.fullText:
*[Rainy all day*]
At Denver - nestled into
Dr Alida C. Avery's lovely guest
chamber again - with dear Dr.
Gleason so attentive so lovely -
what a prize such a daughter
must be to such a precious mother
Dr. R.B. Gleason of Elmiria N.Y
- Dr G. brought me letter from
Sister Mary - written Oct. 3d -7th
& mailed the 8th - waiting to learn
from me how to direct - & quite
as anxious at my silence as I at
theirs - mother seems as well as
before her falls - Miss Hindman
back from Col. Springs - Didn't think
to tell friends to turn to 16th [a??] work -
Somehow - so very few of our speakers
see the practical thing to be done
& dwell entirely on the theoretical
right - instead of the how to get it -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a rainy day in Denver, staying with Dr. Alida C. Avery and receiving a letter from Sister Mary. She also reflects on the practicality of political speeches.

entries.fullText:
Snow this A.M.
At Denver- Dr. A. C. Averys
Another letter from Sister
Mary written Wednesday evening the 10th
& finished & mailed Thursday A.M
the 11th- all seems more
pleasantly hopeful- little Dannie
& all- I do hope he may work
into restful & steady home & school
discipline- I feel, every minute,
the great burden I threw on my
dear & now only living sister Mary
by urging her to take Dannie home
with her-so I hope & hope-
entries.summaryText: Susan writes about the snow in Denver and receiving a letter from her sister Mary about Dannie's progress.

entries.fullText:
[Lusu?] Bright this A.M.
At Dr Avery's - Denver Col
Mrs Richardson called in
A.M. --chatted of Mary L. Boothe's
home & receptions-- in P.M.
Walked to P.O. met Miss Hindman
& then went to Margaret W. Campbells
-she like Miss H & nearly all the W.S.
women-- feels she is really educating people
only when begging round among the
individual "maggots" of their state--
can't take in the wholesale education
of the National Asst method
Letter from Mrs Sargent-good
cheer- attended Mrs R's lecture on the
Augustan age of English literature
John Bunyan, Pope,Addison & Steele, Swift
much the best-- shows more of herself
Sent sister May $100-my pledge to her
if she would undetake the care of Merritt's
little Dannie-- I feel that she
will [?] succeed though with hard work
entries.summaryText: Susan writes about her day in Denver, meeting with Mrs. Richardson and attending a lecture on English literature. She also mentions sending money to her sister May for taking care of Dannie.

entries.fullText:
Lovely ,bright, crisp October
morning-one feels out of doors
the better[?] but I
must dig away at my
"Homes of single Women"
lecture-which grows
slowly indeed-
Dr Gleason took me on
ride after dinner-most
charming two hours it was-
the old mountains magnificent
-then Miss Helen Large with
Miss Hindman from 355
The day has been charming
beyond description-
A letter from Mrs Kelsey-saying
every body was more than satisfied
with my lecture at Boulder-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day in Denver, including working on her lecture, going on a ride with Dr. Gleason, and receiving a letter from Mrs. Kelsey.

entries.fullText:
A regular snow storm
again this A.M.
Went to Mrs Abby Sage
Richardsons lecture on the
novelists of the 17th Century
which I could the 18th-- as her
last close with Goodwine 1789-
She showed more
of herself again
Got letter at 9.30 after
getting home from lecture, from
sister Mary written Saturday Sunday & Monday
all about little Dannie- Saturday
full of hope & promise- but
oh me- Sunday was wholly
discouraging- he seems to be
wholly destitute of moral sense
very smart intellectually
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending a lecture by Mrs. Abby Sage Richardson and receiving a letter from her sister Mary about her nephew Dannie's progress.

entries.fullText: Snowed all day till evening-the [?] off & moon shone delightfully--Could not get on with writing lecture--the terrible trial of my dear & only sister Mary pressed me down terribly- Will she, can she possibly save that boy-- is the question-- got telegram from Slayton saying Sidney engagement was the first--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the snow and her inability to work on her lecture due to the trial of her sister Mary. She also mentions receiving a telegram from Slayton about Sidney's engagement.

entries.fullText: Bright & crisp-ground frozen quite hard-but the sun soon made deep mud of it- Slayton's list of eng'ts from Oct 24th to Nov. 9th came this A.M. --good steady work in Nebraska-- At evening came another letter, dated & mailed the 17th saying Sidney is broken off- so I am in a muddle-whether the Telegram was after the last letter- I tore it-but think it must have been --as it was received yesterday A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the weather and receiving a list of engagements from Slayton. She also mentions receiving a letter in the evening stating that Sidney's engagement was broken off.

entries.fullText:
Temperance & Social [?]
But alas the Rev. F.M. Ellis
who had himself proposed that
I should give my lecture before or
at the Sunday Temp. [?] Meeting
excuses himself that he was
away from home-Friday--&
that yesterday Saturday P.M. the
other ministers of the Temp.Com
Rev. Dr. Lidener, Rev. Dr. Read
M.C. Forester, Gen Champion
Vaughan, Mr Bar? of Chicago
& A.P. Hereford-were to be
the speakers-- Dr Ellis to preside--
The real secret, undoubtedly, is
they feared the Murpheyite
sensation would not be addressed
in their priestly way
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a Temperance & Social event at Foresters Opera House and how Rev. F.M. Ellis excuses himself from the event.

entries.fullText:
There was a general shout
for Miss Anthony last night at the
Temp. Meeting - but it was after
I had left-tired out, with standing
The speaking was terribly stupid-- but
Dr Ellis, they say, redeemed the
evening when he came about 9 oclock
Spent day in packing--& in
P.M. with Miss Hindman & Mrs Mary
Grafton Campbell, visited Wolf Hall
seminary-Mrs Palmer-principal--
where W. D. Anthony's daughters are-
Took early A.M. walk to see the
sun rise on the mountain & to the
P.O. found letter from Sister Mary mailed
the 17th with sequel of Dannies Sunday
exhibit-- I fear it will just make
a finish of her health-but I will
hope not-& that she will make him a god boy
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a Temperance Meeting and Dr Ellis redeeming the evening. She also writes about visiting Wolf Hall seminary and receiving a letter from Sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
Left Denver at 7.30 Dr
Adelle Gleason going Depot with
me-she is charming & strong in
character-It was a sad good
bye to the Halls for poor Mr H
must go over [?] ere long--
The Parsons a pleasant one
& Judge Stiles -the Mayor --
will be found gone with apoplexy
some morning- smart man though
--Had most regret & leaving the
dear old mountains-doubly dear
because my dear sister Hannah last
year in her struggle to live, loved to
linger on them & under them- &
dear Gula too five years ago--
Had pleasant call & ride with Mrs
Amalia P. Post & call Mrs Ann Arnold
at Cheyenne-both very cheery
with Black Hills good luck
in gold & cattle & sheep speculations
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Denver and mentions people and geographical locations she visited and the regret of leaving the mountains.

entries.fullText:
$30.
Sidney-Neb-J.B. Gossage
arrived last night at 8 oclock
stop at Lockwood Hotel-
letter from dear Madam Ameche
saying I was to lecture Milwakee
Nov 18th, must stop with Dr. Ross,
Wrote letter to Lloyd W.
Hixon-M.D. Newburyport
Mass--about taking in his school
-also several other letters-
Had small audience - Mr.
Brainard-wth too much
whiskey, aboard-introduced me
-this was the first lecture ever here
regular barbarian frontier town
-I here close up my Colorado
subscriptions for The B.B. & it is
76--$76-to help on the B.B.-with
in all since new years $281-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Sidney-Neb and mentions people and geographical locations she visited and the lecture she is scheduled to give in Milwakee.

entries.fullText: At Sidney - all day- took train for Kearney at 8 P.M- Got letter from Mrs Williams saying Mrs Kelsey might retain 50 per cent of her B.B. subscription money- have written same to Miss Hindman -I do wish Miss H had more financial sagacity Wrote both Lizzie Boynton Harbertt & Mrs Williams about employing Miss H,-- it does seem as if those who are stationary might undertake to plan canvasses for agents so willing & so able as Miss H.- Mrs Moria Ewing-Sidney Neb going to return to Crete Neb-- Mrs W. H. Weldman- Sidney Neb Miss A.S. Brown " Mrs H.V Redrizton "
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her correspondence with Mrs. Williams and Miss Hindman regarding Mrs. Kelsey's B.B. subscription money. She also writes about canvasses for agents and mentions several people and locations.

entries.fullText: Kearney, Neb -R.H. Easton $20 Reached K. at 6.40 A.M. Stopped Grand Central Hotel- too filthy & too mean cooking for anything-sent $76 .to Ballot Box-- Went to search for the Old Fort-found it to six miles down the Platte river - & only the trees planted by the soldiers left to mark the spot - so didn't go to it- 12 years ago, last August brother Merritt in charge of Kansas 7th Cavalry came out to Fort [Laney?] with wife Mary, [?] & baby boy Dannie of 16 months - What wonder the boy is a rover --he was conceived in roaming & fed on it-- --no letter from sister Mary - & fear she is ill- I should never forgive myself for urging to undertake Dannie & she should break down under it
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her trip to Kearney, Nebraska, and her search for the Old Fort. She also mentions her brother Merritt and his family, and expresses concern for her sister Mary's health.

entries.fullText:
$30
Grand Island-Neb. L.W. Bryan
Took train at 6.40- &
reached G. I at 8.40 - took breakfast
at G.I -- No letters here-
What does it mean - Mary's last
was mailed the 17th telling of
Dannies staying out till 12, mischief
the night before--I shall hope
to night's mail will surely bring one.
Had good Audience-Mrs
Maggie Nultty-ed Granger paper
& their state lecturer introduced me
--Mrs O.A. Abbott- the Lieut.
Governors wife -subscribed for
the B.B.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Grand Island, Nebraska, gives a speech, and meets with local women's rights advocates.

entries.fullText:
At Grand Island-R [?] Hotel
Mr C Wilts Proprietor--formerly
Ed. of Omaha Republican-
Cold, rainy, drizzly day
-not a letter nor paper-
yet-gloomy day - wrote
letters to brothers D.R & J.M -
& one to sister Mary-
Mrs [Molthy?] called & at
evening-Mrs Abbott --& Mrs A.
told me that Mrs Molthy was
very unpopular--& damaged
my impression very much
--said she actually drank to
intoxication &c- It is most
marvelous that such a woman
should thrust herself forward [?]
I felt something wrong --or
very bold & forward about [?]
Took train at 7 AM for Kearny
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a rainy day in Grand Island, Nebraska, writes letters to family, and hears negative information about a local woman's rights advocate.

entries.fullText:
$30
Hastings - Neb - A. S. Wigton
A Horrid breakfast at Kearney- & took
train at 6.40 from Kearney
to Hastings - no letter from
sister Mary - it is very, [?]
strange- - One from
Slayton - changing my plans
so I had to set about the
work of writing to have letters
re-mailed to me
Had fine audience Mrs. A. A.
White - good [?] - state
lecturer introduced me.
Had to take train at
10.45 after lecture - desperately
poor hotel again - it is
strange that women who
have decent homes & could
make me comfortable - will allow
a woman to go to these dirty [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Kearney to Hastings, receives a letter from Slayton, gives a lecture, and complains about poor hotel conditions.

entries.fullText:
$30-
Hebron, Neb - E. M. Correll -
Reached Belvedere at
4 A. M. crawled into bed with
the landlady - & just got to sleep
when I was up & breakfasted & took
stage for Hebron - went to Mrs.
Mary Green's - English - & a very
nice woman - took a good sleep
in P.M. - but found no letters -
I am getting frantic again - at
sister Mary's long silence - can
she be sick -
Had a fine audience & took
stage back to Belvidere at 12
& reached Fairburg at
4 A. M. Went into a bed just
as some man had left for home
& never got warm - feared awfully
that I was getting my death of
cold
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Hebron, gives a lecture, and worries about her sister's silence.

entries.fullText:
[$30.]
Beatrice Neb - Mrs L.W. Colby
Lecture thrown at--
Got up - swallowed slush
for coffee - & crust of a soda
biscuit & was on board stage
at 7.30--had delightful ride from
Fairburg--30 miles to Beatrice
arrived at noon--
Was guest of Mrs Senator
Colby--met there Julia
Coleman--daughter of Charles
Coleman of Rochester--took a
good sleep in P.M.--had a
large audience--M.E. Church
& slept at Pres. ministers--Mr
Vail--Mrs Vail a woman of
remarkable intelligence--
no letters--I am [?]
enough to hear from Mary
& how she gets on with
little Dannie--
Clara Bueck Colby
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Beatrice Neb, meets Mrs L.W. Colby and Julia Coleman, sleeps at Pres. ministers, and hopes to hear from Mary and how she gets on with little Dannie.

entries.fullText:
&30-
Seward, Neb--Thos Wolfe
Left the Vails at 6 A.M.
after little or no real sleep
--waited at Crete 2 hours--
& [Lincoln?]--&--learned that
I am to be sent back to Crete
the 14th & wrote a scolding
letter to Slayton about making
my expenses so great between
my engagements-- also that I saw
no way to connect at C.B. to get to
Sioux City the 8th--he makes
a big muddle of his [?] transfer.
Found letter from sister Mary at
Seward at 4.30 P.M. written 19 & 20, mailed
the 27th of Oct-Is better, stronger courage
& hope of getting Donnie into line
--but the price is eternal vigilance--[holds?]
[him?] of [?] old remembers to keep his head
& hands busy--the minute she lets drop
he runs off & into wrong--So [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Vails, writes a scolding letter to Slayton, and finds a letter from sister Mary at Seward.

entries.fullText:
Ashland, Neb - Ed. J. Hall -
Mr. A. Nichols introduced
-at tolerable hotel
Sat up till 1 AM. that night
& wrote letters - mailed &
Found here at A. two letters
from Sister Mary - written on
[19290-2824] but - still here
hopeful of [ ? ].
Telling that Cousin Albert
had written he didn't want
[Wendell R. Mosher] to work
for him an longer - and
[very sorry? ] - Aunt A. G's was
such a good home for him
- had splendid audience in
the M. E. Church - Mrs.
[Mahoney] - the brightest woman
I met her -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her stay in Ashland, Nebraska, where she received letters from Sister Mary and learned that Cousin Albert did not want Wendell R. Mosher to work for him anymore. She also had a splendid audience in the M. E. Church and met Mrs. Mahoney.

entries.fullText:
Wahoo - Neb - J. B. Davis
Left Ashland at 10 am
by private carriage (couldn't take trunk)
reached Wahoo 24 miles at
2 P.M. - Horse Fair Race
at W. - Hotel packed - at
last got dinner at 2.30 - I
had to lie down to lounge in the
[ ? ] parlor but couldn't
get any rest - was all out of
patience with Mr. Davis for
not getting me a place somewhere
- but had a splendid audience
& made an impression of each
& got 10 subscriptions to the B.B.
- no letters here
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Wahoo, Nebraska with J.B. Davis and attends a Horse Fair Race. She had a splendid audience and received 10 subscriptions to the B.B.

entries.fullText:
left Wahoo - at
10 A.M. - & arrived
at Lincoln at 2 P.M.
25 miles - very cold
& chilly ride - but
soon got warmed & fed.
then read in papers - of
Senator Oliver P. Mortons
death now - 5:30 P.M.
he is to be burried tomorrow
-Mr. Morton has always stood
for Woman Suffrage on
the plan of the Senate.
Phoebe Conyers gone on to
Indianapolis to funeral carrrying
wreath from Mrs. Minor
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Wahoo to Lincoln, reads about Senator Oliver P. Morton's death in the papers, and notes that he was a supporter of Woman Suffrage.

entries.fullText:
Fairmont Neb - R. S. Shepherd
Senator O.P. Morton of
Indiana, burried today.
Left Lincoln at 12 noon
Stopped with Mrs. F.M.
Eller - tip top place
& she a real live woman
but like Mrs. Colby at
Beatrice hampered by
husband not a full believer.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the funeral of Senator O.P. Morton in Fairmont Neb and notes that Mrs. F.M. Eller is a supporter of Women's Suffrage but is hampered by her husband's lack of support, similar to Mrs. Colby in Beatrice.

entries.fullText:
3/5
Nebraska City W.T. Canada
Abandoned
Election Day
$30-
Sidney - O. W Murphy
entries.summaryText: Entry about abandoning something on Election Day in Nebraska City, Canada. Mentions O. W Murphy.

entries.fullText:
Blair Neb V. G. Lautry
Sidney - Io - O. W. Murphy
entries.summaryText: Entry about V. G. Lautry in Blair, Neb and mentions O. W. Murphy in Sidney, Io.

people: Mrs. Nellie M. De Bell [?] City Neb
entries.fullText:
Sioux City IA - E.[?} Skinner
spoke in some opera house
as six years ago when on way to
California & the legal [?] burned
House of Ill fame. I vow jury were
out 19 1/2 hours & returned verdict of
not guilty for Madame Shaw - a
notorious brothel keeper
Mrs. S. S. Fessender called and
Mrs. Nellie M. De Bell [?] City Neb
L. A. Beggs - Sioux City Ia
Mr. L.P Laweeth introduced me
Mr L. W. Wilkins called
on me - the gent who got up
my lecture 6 years ago -
A terribly snowy, cold
windy day - still a fair house -
- Letter from Sister May [?]
[?], giving better promise - of
if he will - if he can but he
lifted out of his hand [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke in Sioux City, IA and met with various people. She also received a letter from her sister.

entries.fullText:
Yankton, Ia - A.W. Howard
Met Judge Shannon
on the train - his wife
was very enthusiastic - Mrs.
Annie E. Shannon -
Had splendid audience
& made more than ordinary
good speech -
Got Postal here after
lecture - telling of the sudden &
aggravating death of Mrs. S. R. Se
Williams daughter Sibyl who
had been married but one short
year to J. Kent Hamilton -
a terrible blow to that mothers
heart - of the two sisters left
Also a letter from brother
Aaron - sort of cross - out of
patience spirit - because I have
begged him to write just a word
to tell me how got on - if better
[?] was too full of work to do so
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke in Yankton, IA and met with Judge Shannon. She also received news of a death in the family and a letter from her brother.

entries.fullText:
J. D. Ainsworth
left Yankton at 8 A. M.
found at O. letter from
Frank M. Mosher - All well
there - but showing that his
father tries to be ugly toward
brother [?] - how did my
dear sister H. ever get along
with such a sulky disposition
good audience again
while at Depot at Sioux City
I wrote word to dear broken
hearted Mrs. Williams - &
one to [? ? ?]
Draft of Mrs. Knox to him
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travels from Yankton to Onawa, Iowa, and mentions receiving letters from Frank M. Mosher and drafting a letter to Mrs. Knox.

entries.fullText:
At Onawa
Rockwell Hotel
very comfortable indeed
Roast turkey - well cooked-
-wrote all day long - till
I was tired enough - so I
couldn't get to sleep any better
than after lecture - letters
to 14 different persons - all
quite long about Convention
at Washington - not a single
soul called on me during
the day - so I had it
all to myself
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day writing letters to 14 different people about the Convention in Washington, but no one calls on her during the day.

entries.fullText:
Left O at 6:25 A.M. arrived
at Blair across Mo. River Ferry
at noon - found letters from
Wendell with one from Frank & his Pa-
they both show great dissatisfaction
with their place at L. - &
I just hope they'll quit - for
it is time - after relative
employees get so they try
to worry & provoke their
employer - as they would never
think of doing to a stranger -
as Frank's letters clearly show
his Father if not himself to [?]
Letter from Ella Baker Spier
Tekamah - 18 miles north
inviting me to visit her but
it is impossible.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her journey to Blair, Nebraska, and receiving letters from Wendell, Frank, and his father expressing dissatisfaction with their place of work. She also mentions receiving a letter from Ella Baker Spier inviting her to visit, but it is impossible.

entries.fullText:
Left Blair at noon
found Julia Brown Bemis
at Depot - rainy - stopped
with her over night - had
nice visit - she make a
more than ordinary woman -
wife & mother - very sensible -
I feel proud of her - and
Mr. Bemis seems to be
fully emancipated from
overshadowing power of
G. F. Train - & really set
about work & doing well
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about leaving Blair, Nebraska, and staying overnight with Julia Brown Bemis. She describes Julia as a sensible woman and feels proud of her. She also mentions that Mr. Bemis seems to be doing well and is fully emancipated from the overshadowing power of G. F. Train.

entries.fullText:
Left Omaha at 9 A.M.
reached Crete at 2 P. M.
stopped with Mrs.
Leyman - a very lovely
cultivated woman. Mr. L.-
a lawyer & his partner Mr.
Raymond - had a
splendid large & good
audience but the doctor
had put price down
to 28 cts - & paid me only
2/7 - amounting to $26 -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Omaha to Crete, Nebraska and stays with Mrs. Leyman. She attends a speaking engagement with Dr. H. Durham and is paid $26.

entries.fullText:
Left Crete at 2 P. M.
and reached Hastings at
5:20. Ex Mayor A.P. Yokum
met me Depot & took me
to his house - Mrs. A.P. Yokum
& daughter Alice- sat up till
nearly 12. Was called at
3 A.M. Mrs. Y. getting cup
of coffee & then waited &
waited but no Bus. came
& we saw the train pull off at
4 & I left - so lounged
till 8 A. M. then waited &
took train - freight -
for Fairburg at 10 -
It was a fearful
performance
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Crete to Hastings, Nebraska and stays with Ex Mayor A.P. Yokum. She experiences a delay in her travel plans and takes a freight train to Fairburg.

entries.fullText: After a most tedious freight train journey from 10 to 5 - reached Fairburg - stopped with Mrs. Purdy - Couldn't get to sleep - tired & out of sleep as I was - my head reeled on platform - but I went through with speech. Slaytons management thus far is simply fearful breaking up my nights - met here Mrs. Colby of Beatrice & Mr. Malby & wife of Farmont
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Fairburg Neb after a long train journey and met with F. H. Miron, Mrs. Purdy, Mrs. Colby, and Mr. Malby. She gave a speech despite feeling tired and dizzy.

entries.fullText: Took cars at 8 for Hannover & thence carriage to Washington, Kan where I found Mrs. Roland of Clarinda, Ia keeping the hotel - And they at once said I must lecture - so they got Pres. Church - sent boy out to ring bell and cry [?] Authors to Lecturers tonight & I had a good audience & got 13 subscribers for B.B. & [?] Col beside - I do really believe Kansas settlers are more wide awake than any others
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled to Washington, Kan and stayed at a hotel run by Mrs. Roland. She gave a lecture and gained 13 subscribers for B.B. and [?] Col.

entries.fullText:
At Washington Kan -
at Mr & Mrs. Roland's Wash. Hotel
Mr & Mrs. Ball came to
dinner & I felt obliged to
visit & thus tired myself out -
Mrs. B takes the woman's
journal - the only one in town
& my 19 B.B's will make a big
wave to swallow that one up
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Washington Kan and how she felt tired after visiting Mr & Mrs. Roland's Wash. Hotel. She also mentions that Mrs. B takes the only woman's journal in town and her 19 B.B's will make a big wave to swallow that one up.

entries.fullText:
Clay Center - J. P. Campbell
stopped with the Campbells
wife Nellie Hosmer
Cousin Ira Howe's son
Byron Howe & his wife
of Zahnsville, Cloud
Co. Kan & her aunt Mrs.
Julia Welch of Cawker City
Mitchell Co. Nan & her son
drove in 17 miles to see and hear
me at this point - looked
sad and worn
Head large fine audience
& got through with speech
But was a good deal troubled
hoarse & severe pressure of
chest & lungs all day - hope it is not
to begin with colds on lungs - if it
is - may as well give up that my
lungs are on way to trouble
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Clay Center and how she gave a speech to a large audience. She also mentions the people who visited her, including Cousin Ira Howe's son, Byron Howe, and his wife, and Mrs. Julia Welch of Cawker City. She also expresses concern about her health, as she was hoarse and had a severe pressure on her chest and lungs all day.

entries.fullText:
[?] at Clay Center
Clark M. Anthony of
Virginia stock - his grand-
father's name was Christopher -
Byron Howe & his
wife called again -
they seemed very sad &
disheartened - I gave
her #2 to start home with
her Aunt Mrs. Welch a
sprightly go ahead woman
I had to stay till 6:20
for train - got into Junction
City too late for a train
this night - stay at hotel
& then drag all
day to Ellsworth [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about meeting Clark M. Anthony of Virginia stock, Byron Howe and his wife. She gave money to Mrs. Welch and had to stay at a hotel in Junction City.

entries.fullText:
Ellsworth Kan. G. A. Atwood
Left Junction City
at 10:20 and dragged
westward on freight train
till 7:30. Mr. Atwood
was at cars - took me to
his house where was
most elegant cup ofoffee - which with an
Egg beaten up - I took -
washed, combed, dressed
& was on platform - a
shoe box by 8 o'clock
but alas - my cold was
too bad - & broke into a
cough ever so many
times - felt all the while
I could never get through
but did 1 1/2 hours
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her journey from Junction City to Ellsworth and her visit to G. A. Atwood's house.

entries.fullText:
J. H. Lockwood
Miss Dr. Anna Warner -
called - took me to ride
with gay gray white horses
& buggy - a splendidly
sunny & warm day -
several people drove
in 12 & 16 miles to hear
me - the M. E. Church
folks cleared $75 on [?]
and felt pretty happy -
Left Ellsworth at 6 A.M.
Sister Ma
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is taken on a ride by J. H. Lockwood and Dr. Anna Warner in Salina, Kan. She speaks at the M. E. Church and raises $75.

entries.fullText:
Left Salina at
7:20 A.M. - met Mrs.
Starrett at Lawrence
Depot - she is editing
or helping on Tribune
looking very well -
but poor Mr. Starrett
looking sadly thin &
pale - met B. F. Akers
Judge Thatcher & Mrs.
W. Reynolds of Journal
who promised to make tour
with G. F. Train 10 years ago
but backed out - nephew Frank,
Sister Annie & D.R. Jr. met
me at Depot - Maria &
Susie B. both sick with chills
& brother D. R. in Chicago
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Salina to Lawrence and meets various people at the depot. Her family members meet her at the depot, but some are sick and her brother is in Chicago.

entries.fullText:
At Leavenworth
Cloudy & in P. M.
rainy - Sister A. took
me in carriage to Sterns
& had bonnet trimmed for
winter - $4.50 & to [Shriverman's?]
& got gloves, under wrappers, cuffs
stockings corsets - in all $10.50 -
charge to brother D.R.

Sister Mary's letter of
School Master Pierce - to
School Board - returned
from Salina - here -
- Mr. P. claims to have
been married July 2nd - &
the facts have him not
to have been till Oct, 2nd
--his is the 2nd school master
crime with school mistresses
this last year -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Leavenworth and goes shopping with Sister A. and charges it to brother D.R. She also receives a letter from Sister Mary about School Master Pierce's false marriage claim.

entries.fullText:
At Leavenworth - Kan
Brother D.R. returned
at 11:20 A.M. from Chicago -
looking very well -

Maud had a chill & looks
very puny & peaked - only
quinine is administered
- Frank & Eugene spent
the evening - both looking
well - though Frank
had four days of
chill of & fever -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Leavenworth and her brother D.R. returns from Chicago. Maud is sick with a chill and Frank and Eugene visit in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Left Leavenworth
at 9 A.M - Mrs. L. G.
Ferry & Mr. T's niece Amelia
Parker - on board - to
go to Fort Scott with Mrs
J. W. Ferry - who is
taking body of her husband
home to bury - he died
of hemorage yesterday P.M -

Found brother J. Merritt
at Depot - with a splendid
gray horse - their parlor
looks very nicely with its
brussels carpet - red - & brown
& red lounge & piano- & nicely
flacked stone - indeed
the entire house looks very cozy
Dolly looks better - Annie, Burt
nice babies - & Mary grown very stout
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Leavenworth to Fort Scott with Mrs. J. W. Ferry and others, and visits her brother J. Merritt.

entries.fullText:
Fort Scott - Kansas
Dr. Sarah C. Hall
Mrs. Eliza Ann Farnsworth
Julia E. Randolph -
Mrs. Imogene N. Gates
Oswego - Kan
Cold raw day
Mr. J. M. Ferry buried
here to day -

Somehow a cloud
over Sister Mary L., she
is just out of a sick
head-ache perhaps that
is the cause - Then, too, I
told her of their [?] tricks
at R. - and Sister Mary had
not done so -& she feels that
he is not to be relied on as
she had hoped -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the funeral of J. M. Ferry in Fort Scott and mentions a conversation with Sister Mary L. about someone's unreliability.

entries.fullText:
Left brother Merritt at
12.01 midnight & arrived
Chetopa at 4 A.M - found
"no fire" in parlor or bedroom
for me & after waiting for
fire to warm room off the
Parlor went up & opened the
two beds-& lo! both had been
slept-then came the
hunt & routing round for
clean sheets-so it was nearly
6 A.M. before I got in bed-
slept till noon- poor everything
for dinner-fine audience.
real winter is set in-
Mr Caveness good-Col Cook
said we are friends to both the
[?] [?] [?] [?] [?] [too] [?] [our] [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Chetopa, Kansas and had trouble finding a warm room to sleep in.

entries.fullText:
Left Chetopa at 11.35
took sleeper & reached A.
at 6.20 A.M. - find better
hotel -- a little - but oh the
coffee & everything - so unbearable

The Woman's Journal of
Nov. 24th says it has sent
out with every number that
week a form of 15th Am't
petition - the A.W. S.A. has
always believed is 15th am't
but more in states' rights [?]
glad they are driven to
make that avowal at last.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Chetopa and arrived in Appleton, Missouri where she found a slightly better hotel but the coffee was unbearable. She also read about a petition in The Woman's Journal.

entries.fullText:
Clinton Mo. Lingle & Mitchell
T.J. Lingle - Ed Democratic paper
stopped at Darius Sullivan's
the post master's
arrived 7 A M found very
nice & clean - Miss Mary
Corliny - Mrs. Harnish C is
Sullivan's sister - Mr. S. went
to school at No. 5. Rochester
to me - Mrs. Amelia
Ryder - a German - called.
also Mrs. Jones - Edited the
Repub. paper
Had splendid audience in a
new Hall - strong with lime
steam - but went without
coughing in spite of it - the
Dem. Eds. made at least $100
on me
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Clinton Mo. and meets with various people, including T.J. Lingle and Mrs. Amelia Ryder. She speaks to a large audience in a new hall.

entries.fullText:
Lexington - Mo.-
R. Trotter
left C at 8 AM. stopped Vidalia
to 1.20 - Reporter interviewed me
- reached Le. at 6.30 -
found no room engaged or
warmed - Mr. Trotter
professed the neglect was
his uncertainty of my coming
perfectly shabby - was trouble
had fair audience in
cold hall - mostly old
slave holders & their
children - very cold
night
The Ed. the Register
Mr. [crossed out] called fine looking
Democrat
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Lexington, Mo. and speaks to a fair audience in a cold hall, mostly consisting of old slave holders and their children. She also meets with R. Trotter and is interviewed by a reporter.

entries.fullText:
My dear Mother-
Lucy Read Anthony-
this day completes her
84th year - & enters upon
her 85th - - And this day
too is the 16th anniversary of
the Hanging of Old Capt. John
Brown, at Harpers Ferry - 16
years since that dread deed - & the
splendid meeting in Corinthian
Hall Rochester - & Parker [?]
grandest speech of his life -
Couldn't get about writing
to dear Mother - was too sort
of unsettled in dark room on
open square of City Hotel -
Mr Trotter called in P.M. &
walked with me to Old Masonic
College - where Milligan was [?]
& Price [?] - every
thing is slow & slave like
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her mother's birthday and the anniversary of the Hanging of Old Capt. John Brown. She also mentions various geographical locations and people she encountered.

entries.fullText:
Left Lexington at 7. last night
arrived here at 10. am
very comfortable at Carroll House
Mr & Mrs Mc[R?] both polite.
Got letter from John E. Fulton
Pres. Lecture Bureau of
San Francisco- offering me 35
per cent of gross receipts for a
lecture tour in Cal - guess
not quite so low as that -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travel to Carrolton Mo and receiving a letter from John E. Fulton offering her a lecture tour in Cal.

entries.fullText:
Left Lexington at 8 A.M.
reached Moberly at 10. I
found Mr. Codding Mason
at telegraph office - went
with him & dined - &
then took train for
Paris at 1 P.M.
Found Mr. Robinson the
son of Loyal widow who
with a sister lives with them
very pleasant family [?]
He a lawyer & books on
table show of good culture
Roads very rough -
Still a large audience
Sat with & lunched &
talked till midnight
then took train
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Paris, MO and meets with Temple B. Robinson and Mr. Codding Mason before speaking to a large audience.

entries.fullText:
Left Paris at 12.45 &
reached Moberly at 6 A.M.
Slept at Merchants till
9 - took breakfast then
left at 10.30 & reached
Mexico at 2 P.M.
Stafford Hotel - Mr. Grove
the P.M. Lost one foot in
the war. Many of my
audience - an immense
one - were old secessionist's
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Mexico, MO and speaks to an immense audience, many of whom were old secessionists.

entries.fullText:
Left Mexico at 2.45 A.M.
reached Moberly at 4:20 & slept
till near 11 - Then breakfasted & took
train to Hannibal then to
Quincy arriving at 6:20 P.M.
Mrs. Abby Holloway - of
Holly - Orleans Co - N.Y.-
the mother of Mrs. Lizzie Long
with whom I stopped-
Had fine audience
though roads were
never so muddy -
Mr. & Mrs Long correct
excellent people -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Mexico to Quincy, Illinois, where she stays with Mrs. Lizzie Long and speaks to a fine audience.

entries.fullText:
Left Barry at 9:30
A.M. - reached Quincy
at 12 - dined (poorly enough)
at Quincy Hotel - took
train for Keokah at 4 P.M.
& thence to Eldon Ia
arriving at 10.20 - the Rock
Island train - behind
I heard the old Engine
puffing back & forward
all night - & in A.M.
found I had had a
dog in my room all
night - heard one scratch
at door - but thought him
outside - was too tired
to know where or what
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Barry to Eldon, Iowa, and spends the night with an unexpected guest in her room.

entries.fullText: Took a freight train from Eldon at 7.30 - & reached Washington at 12. Went to Mr. Everson's a brother in law of Mr. Burrell whose wife had died since I was here - & he & his three children live at Mr. Eversons - Had fair audience & gave Homes for Single Women for the first - but it isn't complete at all yet needs a whole months work on it
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a freight train from Eldon to Washington, Iowa to visit Mr. Everson, the brother-in-law of H. A. Burrell, who recently lost his wife. She gave a speech on Homes for Single Women, but the project still needs a month of work.

entries.fullText: Spent Sunday at Mr. Eversons - not going out - but writing & resting Mr. & Mrs. Clark Conger called on me Miss Jackson - who has for years lived with the Congers is about to be married to Burrell & his three children
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent Sunday at Mr. Everson's and received a visit from Mr. and Mrs. Clark Conger. She also learned that Miss Jackson, who had lived with the Congers for years, is about to marry Burrell and his three children.

entries.fullText: Left here on the 5 A.M. train - waited at Columbus Junction till 10 - thence to West Branch - hotel an old underground R.R. man - James Underwood - called on me - a Quaker - as are most of the people here - said old Capt. John Brown had stopped with his negroes with him many a time. Took Redeye to West Liberty at 7 A.M. then stopped to 11 oclock - called on Anna Ross and gave her four dollars to [?] send Susie B Annie, & Gula - and a little [?Quaker ] doll
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to West Branch, Iowa, and meets with a Quaker who tells her about Capt. John Brown. She also visits West Liberty and gives money to Anna Ross.

entries.fullText: Took carriage from Davenport to Moline reached there at 4 P.M. Had good audience & learned afterward that my hostess had tried a marriage experiment with a widower with sons - endured it 5 years then sent them & him out of her house - a mad heroic act - & one that can be done only when the wife owns the house
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Moline, Illinois, and speaks to a good audience. She learns about her hostess's experience with a failed marriage experiment.

entries.fullText: Thomas G. Ayers stopped with Mr & Mrs Richardson - Danker- Mrs Dout drove me across bridge & through Rock Island Arsenal grounds. Weather -- perfectly delightful - & told me of dear Mrs Sayles sad [exheument] - Took train at 1. P.M. - & reached Cambridge at 4. Mrs. R. gave me a lunch & I went to bed -- had splendid audience -- though mired feet deep -- many waggon loads came 214 miles -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Cambridge, Illinois, and has a delightful day with Thomas G. Ayers and Mrs. Dout, and gives a speech to a splendid audience.

entries.fullText: Went into Chicago, on the C.B & L. & spent night at Aunt A.E. Dickinsons. Poor Kendall (nephew) feels badly to be earning only $6. a week & paying [?] for his board - eating out of the little he has ahead for his washings & extras - arrived at 8. evening -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Chicago and spends the night at her Aunt A.E. Dickinson's house, where she learns about the financial struggles of her nephew Kendall.

entries.fullText:
C.R. Conable
Ed.- The paper.
Curt. No. Treat Clinton was
Ed - Independent both
young & full of enthusiasm
for W.S.
Took train from Chicago
at 9.20 - Slayton met
me at Depot. Thinks he
has done well for me -
better than for Mr. Stanton
or Phoebe - but it is poorly
enough - two long journeys
Took freight at 11 P.M.
to Clinton - Slept - or tried to
till 4.20 - then took cars
to Milwaukee--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Chicago to Milwaukee via Clinton, meeting with various people along the way.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Milwaukee
Reached my friends
Dr Laura J. Ross Wolcotts
471 Milwaukee Street--
at 10 A.M.--found
her in great excitement
Cook had left her--
but I soon tried to get
about furbishing up my
"Homes" but alas it
was impossible--so I
decided to give "Social
Purity"--no letters, no
Ballot Boxes--no petitions
here--It is a shame
it must be Slayton's
fault
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Milwaukee and stays with Dr. Laura J. Ross Wolcott, but is unable to work on her 'Homes' project due to a lack of resources. Instead, she decides to give a talk on 'Social Purity'.

entries.fullText:
E.F. Strickland guest of Dr. E. B. Moleatt - and wife Laura J. ? -
Had a splendid audience - a gone Society Purity - told the people --
I gave it because it was preforatory to single women's homes.
But it is a terrible lecture - going to the root of things.
Madam Duneke and dauther came to dinner and veg may friends called in early
took train at 12 midnight.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture on Society Purity to a splendid audience in Milwaukee, Wis. E.F. Strickland was a guest of Dr. E. B. Moleatt and his wife Laura J. Madam Duneke and her daughter came to dinner and friends called in early. She took the train at 12 midnight.

entries.fullText:
A. W. Kimball arrived at 6.20 A.M.
Stopped hotel - a lady Dr, E.W. Anderson formerly of Ransville, ?
Motor care - called - is just married and evidentally taken off her feet.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met A. W. Kimball who arrived at 6.20 A.M. in Green Bay, Wis. She also met a lady named Dr. E.W. Anderson who is just married and evidently taken off her feet.

entries.fullText: Letter here from brother P.M. about taking my Mary to loan at 10 [?] percent - send him first $100 from her Left G.D. at 9.30 A.M reached Plover at 2 & by stage to Steven's Point at 3-had dinner of beef steak - & then to bed Got letter from hotel May & Mrs Stanton - Dannie had been a good boy for almost a month - Mrs S. had called at No 7
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about receiving a letter from her brother P.M. about taking her Mary to loan at 10 percent. She also mentions her travel to Steven's Point, getting a letter from May and Mrs. Stanton, and Mrs. S. calling at No 7.

entries.fullText: Left S. Point at 8. A.M - Carriage to Plover - mud & slush - 5 miles - then freight to New London & thence freight to Appleton arriving 4 P.M. - & long trunk had been set off at Hortonville - so I had to get my beef steak - go to bed - but couldn't get to sleep & go to Platform in my traveling gear - was [?] by Prof Sawyer- of the Lawrence Union here had [?] but didn't feel at home in my mohair gray travelling [?] The son of Oliver Addcook of Union Village Washington Co lives here & spoke to me.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travel from Steven's Point to Appleton, her long trunk being set off at Hortonville, and meeting Prof Sawyer and the son of Oliver Addcook of Union Village Washington Co.

entries.fullText:
Miss A. E. Brown--
Left Waverly Hotel at
8 A. M. --first class breakfast--
stopped at Oshkosh from 9. to 1-
Discovered another cold
creeping over me Tuesday A. M.
-& today it is in the
sneezing stage -- it does seem
outrageous that I can't keep
them off-- Mud - Mud
stopped 4 hours at Ripon
Woods Hotel -- Met Mrs.
Wolcott at Depot going to Berlin.
Mrs Harris lives Ripon --also
Mrs Brown --good friends
Had small audience at
Berlin. Awfully muddy -- but
cordial welcome from friends.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Berlin Wis and meets with friends despite having a cold.

entries.fullText:
Left Berlin at 8. A.M.
stopped at Mrs Bellus'
Mrs Wolcott went back
to Ripon with me -- had to
stop 2 hours at [Korion?] --then
freight 5 hours to Portage-- then
2 hours & supper at P.
Then train to Camp Douglass--
then Sleeping Car to
Menominee from 8.30 to
2.52-- went to Cap.
Wilson's -- home of Eliza
J. Wilson -- & to bed & slept
till 10 O clock--
Mailed letter with
$100. Draft on Paris Mo.
Bank from Portage
to Mother P. M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Berlin Wis to Menominee and mails a letter to her mother.

entries.fullText:
John Hopewood is
a clerk of Capt. Wilson's
and Englishman of 25-& 5 years
over here-addicted to drink
& reclaimed & fathered & mother
in the Wilson family-
The weather perfectly
awful-murky, drizzly
& the mud without precedent.
Small audience-fearfully
dark withal- & I gave
my Homes of Single Women-
Wis state flat & unprofitable
- I do not believe I shall ever
be able to make but the one
satisfactory speech-& that is my
Bread & Ballot-or Power of
the ballot - that tells all in
a nut shell. Letter from Mary here.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a speech about Homes of Single Women in Menomonee-Wis to a small audience. She received a letter from Mary.

entries.fullText:
At Capt. Wilsons-
Spent day writing a
half dozzen letters-
and more of it talking
talking-Eliza is of a
first Marriage also Tho's B.
-the second family is is 7
living-two dead--5 girls &
2 boys-& of 2 girls [?] & one boy--
Nellie of 22, engaged to Wm
Mead-R.R. Conductor - he
says of 36 - but Eliza thinks
fully 46 - a widower-[?]
does look like the eagle carrying
off the young chicken in his
talons-she very lovely-the
other two girls are Angie
& Sadie 13- very bright & lovely
but it is so sad to see them
one after another lose themselves in [?] marriages--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day writing letters and talking with Eliza and others at Capt. Wilsons. She observed the engagement of Nellie to Wm Mead and expressed sadness over the other girls' marriages.

entries.fullText:
Left Menonimie
Mr Mead also- at
11 A.M- reached
St Paul at 2.30 P.M.
& left there at 4.00 for
Owatonna Minn. arriving
at 8.30 -- It was too
cruel to have to go through
one edge of St Paul Mins-
without a glimpse of
Minnehaha-Laughing
Waters-but -no escaping
the streets were[?]
Slush hub deep- & it
was utterly impossible to drive
the 8 mules out -even if
I had had time --Mr
Mead said he & Nellie had
it all fixed if the family didn't but I [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mr. Mead left Menonimie and arrived in Owatonna, Minnesota. They passed through St. Paul without seeing Minnehaha-Laughing Waters due to the streets being too slushy.

entries.fullText:
Rochester-Minn
J.A. Leonard
Left Owatonna at 10.50 A.M.
Oh that it were "A
Merry Christmas" to
all the world-nay all
the worlds-How very
narrow we are when we think
of the well being of our little planets
[?]- & forget the [?]
myriads of all the others
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Rochester, Minnesota and reflects on the well-being of the world during Christmas.

people: Uncle John Anthony's son David Anthony
entries.fullText: B Shaver Mr Fairchild-Banker met me at Depot- & took me to the home of Uncle John Anthony's son David Anthony - he died Feb. 1877 Mrs Myra Anthony
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the home of Uncle John Anthony's son David Anthony in Kasson--Minn.

entries.fullText: Left K. 1 P.M.-D.C. at 2- Mr Phillips is a Rochester man- stopped at Kinneys Hotel -smaller audience - Mr P said it lacked $5. of covering expenses- the weather is fearfully dreadful-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Dodge Centre - Minn and speaks to a smaller audience.

entries.fullText:
Left J.C. at [*unintelligible*]
Up at 6:20 Mr. A,
Knight-an old [*unintelligible*]
[*unintelligible*] His wife's sister Miss Laura Me
Delano-with him-&
keeps Louise for him--
both spiritualists -
Staffers at hotel-
had a fair coincidence.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about leaving J.C., meeting with Mr. A, Knight, Miss Laura Me Delano, and Louise, all spiritualists, and having a coincidence at a hotel.

entries.fullText:
Left M Peters at 7 A. Me, arriving
U-B at 3 P. nb,- Found good letter from sister Mary- *unintelligible*
report of *unintelligible*- But from dear
mother more entangled in the
marches of her imaginings- it is
too cruel that the intellect want
go farther than the body
Oh if I could have sister
Mary- all I have left - for them
[*unintelligible*, *unintelligible*] ways, so weary
left- allows does come crushingly
over [*unintelligible*]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about leaving M Peters, receiving a good letter from her sister Mary, and feeling frustrated with her mother's mental state.

entries.fullText: This day closes sister Gulema's husband - Aaron McLeans 65th year & begins his 66th - suppose Maggie has the roast turkey for her Paw - All of dear Gulas family gave but dear Maggie & her three - the husband seems no longer a part of her - as of yore - Am at La Crosse Wis - as this day & year closes - at the International Hotel - on way to Spring Valley Minn. where I am to begin the New Year of 1878 - How thought will fly round to all the loved ones - living & dead - gone - & how lonely I feel with only one sister left out my three -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the passing of Aaron McLeans, the husband of her sister Gulema, and her feelings of loneliness as she travels to Spring Valley, Minnesota to begin the New Year of 1878.

entries.fullText:
Janet Norton - New Orleans

Stroudsburg Monroe C. Penn
is the prime mover of the
Tax-paying Women's Petition
in New Orleans last winter
entries.summaryText: Janet Norton is in New Orleans for the summer and Stroudsburg Monroe C. Penn is the prime mover of the Tax-paying Women's Petition in New Orleans last winter.

Barry - Pike Co - Illinois

- Ms Lydia E. Decker
got letter from Miss Decher
saying she read it
